. Hi Peter,
As for the whole mess of apps, some of them are "zombie" containers that got created in the background and never been deleted. Previous versions of Kitematic doesn't notice apps created on the Docker host (had to create through the GUI). With the current version of Kitematic, the Docker host is fully transparent to you, so you can manage your resources properly and delete the apps you don't want.
Sorry about the confusion. The app is still very early and there might be some backward incompatible changes. Definitely feel free to reach out to us if you need more help with the app.
. @Peeja The Kitematic app tries to restart containers that are shutdown (red apps), because we want to restart all the apps that are dead after the Docker host dies or the computer is restarted. Some containers don't have a prolonged command to run (like a running server) and that's why they kept turning red after the command is executed.

We should improve upon Hub and make an even better image browsing experience on Kitematic to improve the experience of using Docker overall.
My suggestions on the UX:
1. Infinite scroll is preferred more than page selectors. Since our users are "browsing" images, we'd want them to have a similar experience to most websites such as Pinterest, Facebook etc.
2. If infinite scroll is challenging or has performance issues, we can fallback to page selector. I think the page selector component can simply stay at the bottom of the page rather than fixed at the bottom. When users scroll down, they can already see that there are more pages.
3. There is no reason to limit the number of pages shown to only 3 (we can bump up the number or use a pattern similar to Google's page selector). One advantage to having page selector is quick access to memorized page numbers.
4. The page selector no longer disappears when the page is loading on Hub. If we are using page selector, Kitematic will feel much more smooth and slick if the selector doesn't appear and reappear when pages are loading.

. Thanks for reporting this. A temporary fix is to remove the old boot2docker VM by running boot2docker delete on the command line and/or deleting the VM in virtual box.
Old versions of boot2docker didn't add an ssh key to support the boot2docker ssh command, and the Kitematic installer assumes boot2docker is already setup correctly with SSH (which it isn't if you're using an old version of boot2docker).
Working on a fix for this now that makes sure the right version of boot2docker is setup so this doesn't happen anymore.

. I just was able to reproduce this. Looking into what's going on now. As for what happens in the installer:
Essentially we:
1) Set up VirtualBox if it's not installed
2) Set up boot2docker & run boot2docker init & upgrade (but use a different vm called kitematic-vm)
3) Add a file to /etc/resolver/kite to forward *.kite dns requests to 172.17.42.1 (the docker bridge)
4) Set up routing from 172.17.0.0/16 to 192.168.60.103 so the docker bridge is accessible to your mac
5) Download ubuntu:14.04 and a kite-dns image which takes care of handling dns requests to the docker bridge

What would be your ideal behavior of Kitematic for this image? That will help us work together on a fix :smiley: 
Note: Kitematic defaults the to running the command in the CMD directive specified in the image's Dockerfile when it starts the container. In this case there doesn't seem to be a CMD directive. It looks like on the CLI workflow you specify the bash command which keeps the container alive. Kitematic is bad at running these containers in general, since it runs /bin/sh by default.
Some ideas to fix this:
- Small fix on this meanjs image: Add CMD mongod to the Dockerfile. This will run the MongoDB process by default.
- Make Kitematic run some long-running process by default instead of /bin/sh so the container stays alive (by default).
Thoughts?

. As @johncokos mentioned, this is almost certainly caused by some software removing VirtualBox's host-only network (which is used to connect to the VM) from your Mac's routing tables.
Re-installing VBox or deleting the network interface essentially puts the routing table entry back. The docker-machine and us are working on a fix for this. Thanks for the info and stay tuned!
. As @johncokos mentioned, this is almost certainly caused by some software removing VirtualBox's host-only network (which is used to connect to the VM) from your Mac's routing tables.
Re-installing VBox or deleting the network interface essentially puts the routing table entry back. The docker-machine and us are working on a fix for this. Thanks for the info and stay tuned!
. This is a general error for anytime docker-machine create hangs. Here's an update on some known problems & fixes:
Mac OS X
- VPN is blocking access to the VM
Windows
- Occurs when VT-X is disabled, enable VT-X
- VPN is blocking access to the VM

. @TechJournalist a current workaround, assuming you've got the Toolbox installed:
- Close Kitematic
- Delete the current default VM: docker-machine rm -f default
- Create a new default machine docker-machine create -d virtualbox --virtualbox-hostonly-cidr "192.168.99.1/24"
- Open Kitematic and it should be using this VM.
As for making this doable via the GUI, I think eventually we'll want KM to be configurable to point to any host but this is work in progress. Check out https://github.com/kitematic/kitematic/pull/876 for a cool example of a team at the DockerCon 2015 hackathon (see #3, Lightning Kite) https://blog.docker.com/2015/07/highlights-dockercon-2015-hackathon/

. Thanks for the issue.
Kitematic is an electron app (powered by chromium embedded framework), and in this case, renders the preview in a webview. Calls to alert will be handled by chromium and show a dialog window (as in the image you showed), like a regular browser.
It does execute arbitrary Javascript as a browser window. But this javascript is contained and should absolutely not have access to node libraries such as fs, net, etc. From the Electron docs:
Different from the iframe, the webview runs in a separate process than your app; it doesn't have the same permissions as your web page and all interactions between your app and embedded content will be asynchronous. This keeps your app safe from the embedded content.
. Going to close this for now, and thanks again for the issue (and screen shot!)
By all means please re-open if you feel this should stay open or if there are any other webview-related security issues!

mchiang0610:
Hey, 
Kitematic seems to have a conflict with older versions of boot2docker at the moment. We're still looking into this issue. 
In the meantime, some of our users have found success in doing this: 
1. In the terminal run boot2docker delete
2. Open Virtualbox and delete the boot2docker vm
3. Delete all the host-only networks under VirtualBox=>Preferences=>Network=>Host-only networks tab
4. Run the installer again

. We tried live filesystem mount, but it didn't work with databases such as mongodb that require filesystem API - fsync. This is why we moved away from that, and are using unison. 
http://docs.mongodb.org/manual/administration/production-notes/#kernel-and-file-systems 
"MongoDB requires a filesystem that supports fsync() on directories. For example, HGFS and Virtual Box’s shared folders do not support this operation."

. Comment from @cordobo in previous thread in case anyone would like this:
UPDATE:
Changing the GUESTS network from "NAT" to "Bridge" in Virtual Box worked as fine, although Kitematic wasn't able to startup (hanging at 99%). Switching back to "NAT" made Kitematic available again.
ORIGINAL COMMENT:
This solved the problem of having too many redirects (see console output) or getting a "404 image not found" and worked for me on OSX 10.10 with VirtualBox 4.3.28:
Open "Virtual Box > Settings > Network > Host-only-networks"
Select "vboxnet0" and klick on the screw driver (ohhh, the irony...)
Select DHCP-Server and uncheck the checkbox from "Activate Server".
Accept with "OK".
Restart Kitematic.
HTH
Cordobo

. Managed to get this working...
- In VirtualBox...
  - Powered down & removed entirely _all VMs
  - In Preferences > Network, removed all Host-only Networks entries
- From the Uninstalling directions for kitematic:
  - sudo route delete -net 172.17.0.0 -netmask 255.255.0.0 -gateway 192.168.60.103
  - rm -rf ~/Library/Application\ Support/Kitematic
  - sudo rm /Library/LaunchAgents/com.kitematic.route.plist

Started up Kinematic from the command line, went through the setup again, and now it appears to work.
.

. @mk101 when you say "didn't work" do you mean there were filesystem errors? It's kind of funny for MongoDB to require this, since fsync() will cause the kernel to flush its file information to disk, but it's not deterministic at all. The buffers on the hard drive for performance reasons can delay actually writing the data to disk for quite some time. At best it's wishful thinking on the program's behalf, they shouldn't place any solid bets on it.
The sync with Unison will never be "instant" when it comes to moving data into the container. From the container's perspective, it's going to look like files are being streamed onto disk by another process. Unison may shove files into place afterwards, in which case the container's process looking for a particular file will see nothing until it magically appears in whole. That doesn't help containers whose first CMD relies on files being present.
The advantage of a filesystem mount is in fact that the "sync" is instant. When a process inside the container asks for a directory listing, and the directory is backed by a remote filesystem mount made from inside the boot2docker VM, the system call in the VM will block while that data is retrieved. The container will only ever see the true on disk reality, rather than in-progress copy states. This is, on the whole, a lot more desirable.
Everything has tradeoffs, however. You found one, which is that the virtualbox filesystem doesn't support fsync() on directories. You have to decide whether that is a good tradeoff for your user base, which I acknowledge is hard before you actually have a user base :) Another significant tradeoff is filesystem space. For unison you are duplicating all the content inside the container, which eats disk space. Another tradeoff is the setup expense. Unison is easy to set up, while smb or nfs will rely on the vagaries of the host VM OS and require setup on the OS X side too.
I think there are two use cases here to consider.
- content that has to be present inside the container for correct operation. For this, you can't rely on rsync or unison after the container starts, because you can't assume everyone's code is resilient to starting with a partial filesystem state.
  - option 1: start the container in two stages. Invoke /bin/sh as the command, wait for the unison sync to finish, then restart the container with its real command. I haven't tried this but it seems plausible and portable (/bin/sh should always exist). Effectively you're doing the blocking operation on everyone's behalf.
  - option 2: use a remote filesystem mount like nfs or smb.
  - option 3: specify it as an ADD in the Dockerfile, which implies it's a one-way operation.
- content that has to be present inside the container, but won't break container startup
  - unison is fine for that :)

https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/networking/#/user-defined-networks
And explains that Each container in the network can immediately communicate with other containers in the network.

. @blazeeboy Something like this would work:
```
Create a volume for all of the Postgres Data
docker run -d --name pgsql-volume -v /var/lib/postgresql/data tianon/true
Create your postgres container using the volume created above
docker run --name some-postgres -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=mysecretpassword --volumes-from pgsql-volume -d postgres
```
If you need to backup/restore/migrate your data, follow the following:
https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/containers/dockervolumes/#backup-restore-or-migrate-data-volumes

. @dannc @stefanhong There is a misunderstanding here.
Hub is a CMS - Content Management System that provides auth, search, etc.
Registry is a CDS - Content Distribution System that allows you to push/pull your images (like a CDN)
Unless you know what your resource is, very much like a CDN, you can't get that resource. 
For example for you to get an image from CDN you need to know the exact image name, otherwise you get nothing. 
Registry is the same thing, you need to know the exact name of the image before you can pull it.
. @dannc The PR you mentioned was closed as it was created without much knowledge of the CMS/CDS mentioned above. I had the exact same idea as you did regarding pointing Kitematic to the https://localhost/v2 url when the PR was created. The issues mentioned in the comparison of CMS/CDS is what makes it very difficult and makes the PR unusable. 
@jbw91 @dannc maybe what would help is the current usage of your local registry? How do you 'view' images stored? Do you just 'know' what to pull?
Registry being a simple CDS, has no Auth, no Search, no list of User images. This is the 'magic' that a CMS (Hub) adds.

config file setup should be something like .kitematicfg in your user's home directory:
{
    "driver": "vmwarefusion",
    "name": "dockerfuse",
    "memory": "1024",
    "vbinstall": false
}
Description:
- driver: the docker-machine compatible driver (should work with all driver supported by docker-machine)
- name: name of the vm to use
- memory: the ram that can be allocated to the vm
- vbinstall: true/false on installing VirtualBox. Not having VirtualBox installed, setting this option to false and using virtualbox as the VM driver is obviously going to create some issues.

https://github.com/FrenchBen/kitematic/tree/cfg-vm

. ## SOLUTION (or high hopes)
For windows user, assume 'dev' to be 'kitematic'
1. Turn off your VM via the following terminal command docker-machine stop dev 
2. Open your VirtualBox app and go to your Preferences (app preferences, not VM settings)
3. Click on Network, and Host-Only Networks tab
4. You should see a few vboxnet entries, for each one do
   1. Click on vboxnet entry and then click on the screw-driver icon (edit)
   2. Click on DHCP Server tab
   3. On the selected vboxnet, check if DHCP Server is checked - if it is, check if the Server address is: 192.168.99.1 - If NOT, just click Cancel and move on to the next one.
5. Write down which vboxnet0, vboxnet1, vboxnet2 (however many) has the proper setting of DHCP server checked and a Server address of 192.168.99.1 and cancel out of the Preferences
6. Select the dev VM (windows kitematic VM)
7. Click Settings then Network
8. Adapter 2 should be a Host-Only Adapter, and change its name to be the vboxnet you noted above.
9. Click OK and close VirtualBox app
10. In your terminal run: docker-machine start dev then docker-machine regenerate-certs dev
11.  You can now start Kitematic and see it working :)
. ## SOLUTION (or high hopes)
For windows user, assume 'dev' to be 'kitematic'
1. Turn off your VM via the following terminal command docker-machine stop dev 
2. Open your VirtualBox app and go to your Preferences (app preferences, not VM settings)
3. Click on Network, and Host-Only Networks tab
4. You should see a few vboxnet entries, for each one do
   1. Click on vboxnet entry and then click on the screw-driver icon (edit)
   2. Click on DHCP Server tab
   3. On the selected vboxnet, check if DHCP Server is checked - if it is, check if the Server address is: 192.168.99.1 - If NOT, just click Cancel and move on to the next one.
5. Write down which vboxnet0, vboxnet1, vboxnet2 (however many) has the proper setting of DHCP server checked and a Server address of 192.168.99.1 and cancel out of the Preferences
6. Select the dev VM (windows kitematic VM)
7. Click Settings then Network
8. Adapter 2 should be a Host-Only Adapter, and change its name to be the vboxnet you noted above.
9. Click OK and close VirtualBox app
10. In your terminal run: docker-machine start dev then docker-machine regenerate-certs dev
11.  You can now start Kitematic and see it working :)

. @psychemedia The idea is for them to map the volume and just fire up the container without having to import anything.

web:

redis:

. @simoami You're missing out on the magic ;)
Your Redis Host is connected within the container-  So instead of connecting to it via the 192.168.... you just use ENV['REDIS_PORT_6379_TCP_ADDR'] as the host and ENV['REDIS_PORT_6379_TCP_PORT'] as the port in your code. You can also see that the full string is set here: ENV['REDIS_PORT_6379_TCP']
If you look at the /etc/hosts file, you'll see that there's even a host entry for the Redis server and it's associated with the proper IP in there. 
The 192.168.... Ip is only if you wanted to connect to it from outside of a container.

. @dx-pbuckley if you look at the end of the log you provided, the IP for the VM (that the above is trying to reach) is correct: 192.168.99.100
It looks like the DHCP daemon for vbox died, can you ping 192.168.99.100? If not, make sure the VM is stoppped: docker-machine stop defaul, look for a Vbox-like service with the name DHCP in it in your 'Activity Monitor' and kill it. 
Then go ahead and start your VM again docker-machine start default. 
You should now be able to ping it ping 192.168.99.100
If that works, then you can re-try the cert regen command and it should work without issue.

. The issue is the linked to the certificates that should be copied to the machine - Due to some issues with Virtualbox, these certificates are sometimes not properly copied to the VM, causing the issue that you saw. 
Obviously removing the machine and re-creating it forces the certs to be created. There are a couple of issues opened/closed on docker-machine that talk about this. I'm not sure what the proper fix would be.
. Hmm, I'm not sure why the installer steps would fail. But you're right, if the VM takes too long to be created, then it would at some point cause the error you see above. 
Doing a regen on the certs can work if to begin with the networking isn't an issue. As I'm sure you've seen in some of the threads, DHCP from VBox can be finicky and most of the time the root cause of certs not added to a VM.

docker-machine -D create -d virtualbox --virtualbox-memory 2048 default

. That's correct, machine stores all certs it has generated in .docker\machine\certs\ - I don't believe they are regenerated when you create a new VM. It just uses the same ones. (it's all local aka low-risk)
If you want to confirm that, you can look at .docker\machine\machines\default\config.json - You'll see an entry that looks like:
json
"CaCertPath":"C:\\Users\\Josh\\.docker\\machine\\certs\\ca.pem"
The location above was referencing the actual VM path, where the certs are stored. Odd that it would already have them in place if you were just creating the VM.
. Thanks for the great step by step - Your assumption is correct, the network adapter is usually at the core of the issue. (there's a couple of mentions of the steps you just took in the wiki)
What usually happens is this:
Improper connection -> Cannot connect to newly created VM -> Cannot push Certs -> Cannot Docker.
if you're up for it, you can delete all of the Host-Only network in VirtualBox and see if the issue happens again when you create the VM (as above). Even if you uninstall VirtualBox, I think some of those host-only setups are kept within the Registry. 
. Only the first Host-Only interface is setup and used - If you go under the VM's settings > Network, you can see that the VM is using 2 adapters:
- NAT
- Host-Only

. Sounds like it's the source of your problem. Even though the VM is 'up/started' it doesn't look like network is setup till afterwards, preventing Kitematic from displaying the containers.
If your VM can be discarded, it'd be interesting to see if removing it and re-creating it solves this.
docker-machine stop default
docker-machine rm default
Then open the VirtualBox app and under 'VirtualBox > Preference' menu, select 'Network' then 'Host-Only Networks'. 

Delete all Host-Only network interfaces that have been created, then re-launch Kitematic to have it setup the new default VM and associated network interface.

. @alexandrev @tiptronic The issue is no longer man power, but the fact that the code would only work for 1/2 of the solution.

1. Adding the folder entry in Virtualbox is a very manual process, where the options need to be set properly

. My point is that your OhMyZsh may be over-writing some of the env/shell variables that are created with the QuickStart Terminal.
The fact that you don't get anything when you run env | grep -i docker is an indicative that something is being over-written. 
Unfortunately I am not familiar with your particular shell mod and thus can't help much. My only advice is to disable OhMyZsh and see if the QuickStart Terminal works with iTerm + Zsh.
For comparison, I use iTerm + Zsh + Zprezto and never had any issues.

. @alexandrev After some QA I found one small issue.
If you have a port mapped and try to add the same port mapped to a different endpoint, the refresh fails and only 1 port gets mapped. 
For example:
| Container | Mac/Win |
| --- | --- |
| 80 | 8080 |
| 80 | 8081 |

. That's correct - Running containers are the only ones that tie a port; non-running containers wasn't part of the original discussion. 
When you hit save we don't dynamically update the container, we re-created it, which then triggers the 500 error that you're seeing, granted the error should've been more verbosed than [object Object].
In the latest version you will see something like:
(HTTP code 500) server error - driver failed programming external connectivity on endpoint postgres (4e5c8753bcc5b37d4613755a0d1832571da819757f076797dce51417453d2db3): Bind for 0.0.0.0:5432 failed: port is already allocated
I'm not sure if there is a good way to handle this; technically a non-running container should not prevent you from creating another container and using that port.

The issue is the complexity of the corp firewall settings, which involve a bit more than a simple 'flick' of a setting in kitematic. As you can see by the steps described in the wiki, some changes are within the VM on top of Kitematic being ran from the CLI to pickup the firewall details. 
. @mateodelnorte it's a lot more complex than just kitematic - Kitematic is only an interface that talks to Docker. 
This means that if you can't do docker pull  .... via the command line, Kitematic isn't going to magically solve this. Since you're running Docker Toolbox, I would encourage you to read:
https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-mac/docker-toolbox/
The wiki doesn't say to setup a proxy, but mentions that the 'firewall' you mention is more than that, it's really a corp proxy that changes how SSL is handled, as @ajlanghorn your connections to the outside world are being mitm'd. What I mean by this is that instead of doing:
you < ---- > Google
it does:
you < ---- > Corp Proxy < --- > Google (corp proxy is what you call the 'firewall')
some ref on the difference: https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-difference-between-a-firewall-and-a-proxy
What the wiki suggests is to obtain the proxy information as seen above, and simply add them to the VM so that it can talk to the outside world properly. . This is a Windows Container image only - Please see the documentation for this image and the requirements.

WP -> VM -> MySQL -> VM -> WP
With proper container network:
WP -> MySQL -> WP

Since we can't detect the permissions of the shared folder until the container fails, we cannot prevent the user from doing this. Additionally there isn't a wait on the resource from the daemon. 
It is best for the user to check that the folder they're trying to use has the proper permission first, as documented here: https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-windows/#shared-drives
. @Chematronix  Completely understand where you're coming from - When kitematic was first created, one of the biggest problem was sharing volumes with Virtualbox. By default only the "user" directory was shared in order to provide light guard-rails with what could be shared. 
The concept of updating what seems to be your container, by silently destroying it and re-creating one with the same name has caught a few people off guard. With advances in the Docker product being done by multiple people, kitematic simply lacks the resources it needs to capture all use-cases and better the product. 😞

What happens when the env var is set, but the machine doesn't exist?. Here's part of the complexity, say you're doing a lot of docker-machine things and to make your life easier, you set the ENV var to be machine.
In order for the ENV var to be "seen" by Kitematic, Kitematic would need to be started from the CLI (not very convenient for most users)
This VM isn't a boot2docker image, but it's what you use for X project.
You then decide to open Kitematic from CLI, as you've done before, with the changes you've mentioned above. 
It wont connect. You forgot that you had the ENV, and think Kitematic is being silly not finding your default vm and click the "Delete and try setup again". You've now blown away your X project machine and may be mad at Kitematic (even though you told it to do it)
TL;DR - it's easier to tell people that default is the Kitematic preferred VM, and the one that should always be used for boot2docker things, rather than providing complex options as to what VM/Driver combo should be used.

Looking on hub, Elastic decided to deprecate their hub maintenance:
https://hub.docker.com/_/elasticsearch/
I'm not sure why they did that, but I would open a ticket with them to explain how annoying it is that they can't do a simple docker push to docker's hub.. Kitematic is designed to only work on images that are hosted on Docker Hub that's correct - Kitematic is a Docker product, made to work with Docker's registry. 
The image you downloaded via the Elastic registry doesn't have the same namespace as the one downloaded from Hub. This it doesn't actually spin up the same image, and (hypothetically) it's possible that the hub image is intentionally not working, thus forcing the user to lookup where to properly download it. . It's not hard-coded to break for anything, it just happens that the image has different requirements. You see the same error by running it via the CLI docker run elasticsearch - there is no such thing as roadblocks/proprietary code here.

Always restart the container regardless of the exit status. When you specify always, the Docker daemon will try to restart the container indefinitely. The container will also always start on daemon startup, regardless of the current state of the container.

. @jhabdas Apols: that was probably meant to read as something like docker-compose up -d or docker-compose up start.
As to containers appearing in Kitematic, I've noticed in recent versions sometimes they do, sometimes they don't... Not sure how much I trust Kitematic any more:-( Which is a shame, because I thought it held real promise as an app runner for users who won't go anywhere near the command line.... Complementary to docker-compose support is being able to use Kitematic to build and seed a container from a Dockerfile + supporting files.
The original MyBinder project (now part of the Jupyter project as binderhub) would dynamically build an image from a github repo. The O'Reilly Launchbot does something similar on the desktop - but again, without support for docker-compose.
The reason I mention it here is that whilst the proposal for docker-compose support in Kitematic helps those of us wanting to use Kitematic to support use, by non-technical users, of linked Docker containers as part of a personal application workbench, we're still left with the problem of how to distribute things like a files as part of that workbench.
(An example use case might be a non-expert users who knows simple SQL and wants to be able to query across mixed JSON and CSV files from a Jupyter notebook UI using Apache Drill, but who doesn't want to have to worry about installing those applications and setting up the correct links between them. In addition, they may have data files and Jupyter notebooks they want to be able to share with other non-expert users using a similar workbench setup.)
So I'm now imagining the following scenarios:

Kitematic as an application that can pull down pre-built images and launch them
Kitematic as an application that could pull down pre-built images and launch them as part of a docker-compose composition
Kitematic as an application that can build one or more images from a source repo (or config zipfile) and launch them as linked containers
Kitematic as an application that can pull down a pre-built image and then copy in data files from a source repo or zipfile to a linked volume

timelf123:
Using a volume name instead of a local path would be great. Currently doing this instead:
docker volume create --name=mongodata
docker run -d -p 27017:27017 -v mongodata:/data/db --name=mymongo mongodb:3.3. Using a volume name instead of a local path would be great. Currently doing this instead:
docker volume create --name=mongodata
docker run -d -p 27017:27017 -v mongodata:/data/db --name=mymongo mongodb:3.3. >The problem is not the DNS you have, it is the packet return size. Im guessing for 8.8.8.8 the return size is less than 512 bytes. So the UDP packet is forwarded from the vm running on your machine to the host machine. When the DNS returns a packet size over 512 DNS will fall over to TCP, which it looks like the vm is not forwarding to your host machine and thus it cannot resolve.
This was it for me - 8.8.8.8 -> 208.67.222.222  (opendns).
catkins:
I was able to get pow working again by following the uninstall instructions in the README, then reinstalling pow.
For the lazy...
- rm /usr/local/bin/boot2docker
- sudo route delete 172.17.0.0/16 192.168.59.103 (disable routing to containers through VM)
- rm -rf ~/Library/Application\ Support/Kitematic (remove app data)
- rm /Library/LaunchAgents/com.kitematic.route.plist (remove launch job that sets up routing to the containers)
- curl get.pow.cx/uninstall.sh | sh (uninstall pow)
- curl get.pow.cx | sh  (install pow again)

. Can you give a bit more detail?
It sounds like you are having difficulties starting a container from an image called "ubuntu-nginx-mysql-php-nodejs."  I can't find any such image in the hub, so I assume it is a local image, and that the image has inside of it a script /usr/local/bin/start.sh, and the image build uses that as either the entrypoint, or the cmd.
If this describes your scenario, can you manually start the same container?
$/> docker run -d ubuntu-nginx-mysql-php-nodejs
The "permission denied" error could be coming from your host (your desktop) if the desktop user doesn't not have access to start docker containers (on some systems sudo is required,) or it could be coming from inside the container, if you are using an alternate user that does not have permissions to start containers.
. so this looks more like an npm issue than a kitematic issue.  In particular, npm is failing because of file permissions in your tmp directory (which in ubuntu is /usr/{user}/tmp or in your npm folder (which is /home/{user}/.npm"
Can you try explictly setting your TMP path to something which is user-writeable, and chmod-able: https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/2936

. Can you try the following? Possibly try them individually to identify which one fixes it.
Quit Kitematic.app and boot2docker (from Settings or boot2docker stop)
```
if you get an error from delete command, this is probably why your dns was not resolving
sudo /sbin/route delete -net 172.17.0.0 -netmask 255.255.0.0 -gateway 192.168.60.103
let's add the route configuration
sudo /sbin/route -n add -net 172.17.0.0 -netmask 255.255.0.0 -gateway 192.168.60.103
ip addresses are the same everyone.
```
```
relaunch routing
launchctl load /Library/LaunchAgents/com.kitematic.route.plist
```
Launch Kitematic.app again and wait for a while as it starts boot2docker VM. You can confirm the status from the UI or with boot2docker status (should be running).

alankent:
It would be good to be able to use a shell of choice (cygwin comes to mind), or get TERM set correctly or powershell (if such a thing exists) so when you docker exec into a container you can use vi or less. Powershell does not support the xterm escape sequences completely, making vi pretty hard to use.
. What is even more interesting is "Docker Quickstart Terminal" works well on Windows. But Kitematic does not use the same terminal type, using Powershell instead. Even if not configurable, using the same terminal window as Quickstart would be a big improvement.
. What is even more interesting is "Docker Quickstart Terminal" works well on Windows. But Kitematic does not use the same terminal type, using Powershell instead. Even if not configurable, using the same terminal window as Quickstart would be a big improvement.
. +1
We spun up https://docs.docker.com/registry/, added username/password authentication (tied into an internal authentication database, which is why we cannot use DockerHub.com), but then could not work out how to make Kitematic work with it. Unfortunate.. I would like this too, but because when I have a login to the Docker host I want to set TERM to something so I can use "vi" and "less". As far as I can tell, Powershell does not support cursor moving escape sequences, but using Cygwin as the shell does. And export TERM=cygwin seems to be recognized by modern versions of Linux.
If there was a TERM value that supports Powershell that would actually be preferable (for me).

. Using 'less' in busybox gives a fatal error and it drops back to Windows terminal emulator window.
$ docker run -it busybox
/ # less /etc/passwd
FATA[0062] The parameter is incorrect.
$
There is no /lib at all in busybox, so no /lib/terminfo etc describing what "xterm" means. Changing TERM to 'xxxx' does the same thing as "xterm". Basically I think busybox is a super cut down version of binaries with the terminal escape sequences hard coded into the binaries (no way to change it). So it is not useful for testing TERM settings. No matter what TERM is set to, it does the same thing.
Try using ubuntu
$ docker run -it ubuntu
root@9055e364b93d:/# vi /etc/passwd
I did some copy/paste to make file longer, then tried ^Y and ^E (display one more line at top or bottom of screen) - messes up the screen.
root@9055e364b93d:/# less /etc/passwd
Did not abort window immediately, but output was only a single page.
root@9055e364b93d:/# cat /etc/passwd /etc/passwd /etc/passwd /etc/passwd | less
Type 'u' and 'd' to scroll up/down half a page - screen gets messed up quickly.
Looking in /lib/terminfo there are terminal definitions. But 'xterm' (and 'cygwin') does not work well.
Also using vi plays up, but it is worth noting in Ubuntu "vi" is "vim", unlike busybox where "vi" is a special cut down binary with a single terminal type built in.
The fact that 'vi' does work in busybox seems to indicate there is a set of escape sequences that the terminal emulator works with well (ignoring 'less' crashing out for some reason!). I just don't know what terminal type to use for a Linux container that supports TERM settings.
Thanks!

I'm developing on Linux, but I can't include the Linux support in the editable volumes branch, so I have to do some tricking things in order to developer under Linux and provide the feature for the official repository.

The error is more likely to be related to the missing docker daemon - When Kitematic starts (on OSX/windows) it creates a VM to allow docker to function properly, as seen in the Setup.js:
https://github.com/zedtux/kitematic/blob/linux-support/src/stores/SetupStore.js#L153
IMHO the Linux distro should do the same, although it can simply install/setup the docker daemon locally. Usually installed in /usr/local/bin since it won't be a managed package. (unless I missed where this is setup in your PR?)

The PR is not installing Docker as it has to be done using the package manager. This is quite a big job to implement as it should manage all the different Linux distribution.
The purpose of this PR is not to make Kitematic working on a fresh Linux box, it's about to make Kitematic working on Linux, meaning you have a step before which is to make sure Docker is running on your machine.
But I fully agree with you that at the end of the day, Kitematic on Linux should take care to install Docker automagically.
. And BTW the Docker installation should be done as a dependency of the Kitematic package. There's no need for a wizard.
. @TeckniX homebrew on OSX is a young but powerful tool developed by a guy where couple of different people are committing some formulas and all this is installed in /usr/local/Cellar/. Then using some symlinks it makes the system aware of this folder and allow you to use the tools. The Linux package managers in the other hand are fully integrated in the system (you don't maintain OSX itself with homebrew) and all the packages are following a clear guideline with people to validate and maintain security patches and so on (it's not obvious that the packaged software developer is going to patch it).
In addition to that, a Linux user do not work the same way than an OSX or Windows user. When a Linux user want to install something, he will always try to do <insert-your-prefered-package-manager-here> install package-name or use a tool to search for it in the package manager but not going to a website, downloading an archive and double click an installer.
My final point on this is also managing the dependency of docker is very simple with the Linux packages (just a reference to docker in a file) while implementing it in the code would cost a lot of time and even more after in maintenance (keep in mind that Linux distribution born every years).

You can see a parallel with Safari where initially you don't have the developer tools enabled, so that you cannot inspect a page. Then going to the settings, and enabling the option add the new contextual menu entry to inspect a page.

. > Initial load of the 'Volumes' tab did not show the Dockerfile exposed volumes
This is a bug in Kitematic. I have already noticed it but didn't fixed it.
Let say it's the first time you run Kitematic, all is fine. You create container(s) and work with. You will not have this issue.
But now you close Kitematic and later start it again. In this case you will miss the list of created containers, plus opening the 'Settings' > 'Volumes' will not show any entries at all.
A workaround would be to click the 'SAVE' button and then open another tab and come back to the 'Volumes' tab.

The 'empty' folder entry cannot have its local folder modified until you've clicked the :heavy_plus_sign:

I will check that.

redeemed2011:
@zedtux your branch seems to work fine on ubuntu 15.04.
i'd installed docker in the past:
```
install docker
curl -sSL https://get.docker.com/ubuntu/ | sudo sh
add my user to docker group
sudo gpasswd -a ${USER} docker
```
rebooted since then, which i recommend for simplicity's sake, or do this for your current terminal session:
```
restart docker
sudo service docker restart
tell the current terminal about the new docker group changes
newgrp docker
```
to setup kitematic:
```
download kitematic to /opt/kitematic
cd /opt
sudo git clone https://github.com/zedtux/kitematic
cd kitematic/
sudo git checkout linux-support
sudo make
adjust permissions so that anyone in docker group may use kitematic
chmod -R g+w .
chgrp -R docker .
start kitematic
npm start
```

. Yeah that would be the case if this was a regular node project but since it's an Electron app it makes not much sense to track the recommended node versions.
Electron tracks the node version that is nearest the v8 version in the used Chrome and goes through a lot of hassle to make that happen (including patching chrome I think).
In v.0.36.0 they upgraded to 5.1.1 and the current (1.3.5) uses node6.3.0 which maps to Chromium 52.0.2743.82 which is V8 5.2.361.43.
In my opinion it makes not much sense for the reason we discussed early in this thread to track node versions apart from electron. Instead the focus should be on the electron version and the node version that comes with the electron version.
To answer @pmario's question. The electron API is stable since 1.0.0. That means that ones Kitematic updates to a Electron >1.0 it will be much easier to track the latest version (until v2 comes along of course).

I think some tips for a good PR are having screenshots and/or gifs to show what visual changes were made, having good commit messages (like "added sticky feature for containers" and not "test"; you can git rebase your branch to get rid of unnecessary commits and/or edit the messages), having your commits attributed to your GitHub user (currently doesn't look that way), signing your commits (required by kitematic's CoC).

. In case someone is facing the same problem, the one thing that worked for me is to save the file under the new name and from the boot2docker overwrite the original with the copy.
mv file_tmp.conf file.conf
It's a very lame approach and will help only when dealing with not too many files, configs passed to containers in volumes is probably the best example.

. I had a look at that problem and as far as i understand is that the FS/Volume driver of Virtualbox is causing these problems. So there will only be the option to implement something like a network share with the MacOSX host or rewrite the Virtualbox driver. I think mapping a network share CAN also cause some problems with some filesystem operations.
. One example:
You have five developers using kitematic. On every kitematic runs a mongodb container. This container will have another port on every workstation. So every developer has another configuration. DieterReuter:

I'd like to see to support maybe more than a single remote Docker host!

. @jeffdm I just implemented an easy way to connect an external or remote Docker Host. Right now it works fine for me with my existing Boot2Docker VM. But there are some drawbacks with the function call of docker-machine tls-regenerate-certs -f dev, so I had to disable it - but I think this part should be included in a new upstream version of docker-machine.  And I did used my own version of docker-machine and had implemented a special driver to connect an existent Docker Host, this works great now on my Raspberry Pi running Docker 1.5.0.
Everything is included here in my PR https://github.com/hypriot/kitematic/pull/1
Disclamer: that's more a quick hack, but you can see it's easy to do.

. Just use docker-machine env dev to display the settings of your current Docker Host. Or you can use directly in your bash shell the command $(docker-machine env dev) and all settings will be done for you.
Here is a short example:
docker-machine env dev
export DOCKER_TLS_VERIFY=1
export DOCKER_CERT_PATH=/Users/dieter/.docker/machine/machines/dev
export DOCKER_HOST=tcp://192.168.59.103:2376

. @FrenchBen, I decided to move to Docker Toolbox as you suggested. It looks like homebrew had some duplicate tools. I'm putting this here for anyone curious.
``
$ brew uninstall docker
Uninstalling /usr/local/Cellar/docker/1.8.1... (9 files, 8.9M)
docker 1.7.1 is still installed.
Remove them all withbrew uninstall --force docker`.
$ brew uninstall docker
Uninstalling /usr/local/Cellar/docker/1.7.1... (9 files, 7.4M)
$ brew uninstall docker-machine
Uninstalling /usr/local/Cellar/docker-machine/0.4.1... (5 files, 16M)
docker-machine 0.3.1 is still installed.
Remove them all with brew uninstall --force docker-machine.
$ brew uninstall docker-machine
Uninstalling /usr/local/Cellar/docker-machine/0.3.1... (5 files, 16M)
$ brew uninstall docker-compose
Uninstalling /usr/local/Cellar/fig/1.4.0... (374 files, 4.6M)
```
I then installed Docker Toolbox 1.8.1c
The biggest catch here is there is now a docker host named default and my old one is called dev,
so Kitematic 0.8.3 was still looking at the wrong Docker host.
$ docker-machine ls
NAME      ACTIVE   DRIVER       STATE     URL                         SWARM
default            virtualbox   Running   tcp://192.168.99.101:2376   
dev       *        virtualbox   Running   tcp://192.168.99.100:2376
I created this cleanup script to remove all of my containers since I didn't need them. I'm wondering if there is a way I could have migrated them if I wanted to?
I also updated my rc file (for my OSX shell) to point to the new "default" docker host to set up the local environment variables:
eval "$(docker-machine env default)"
Until I updated the eval call in my rc file (which runs anytime I open a new shell), they were still spinning up in my old dev host (because the env variables were pointing at Docker host dev).
I ran docker-machine kill dev to make it inactive. Now looking at the ls command for docker-machine:
NAME      ACTIVE   DRIVER       STATE     URL                         SWARM
default   *        virtualbox   Running   tcp://192.168.99.101:2376   
dev                virtualbox   Stopped
So then I destroyed my old Docker host with this:
$docker-machine rm dev

. Currently, it's not possible to "disable" a volume if an image defines one. There's work in progress to allow UNSET-ing properties. See https://github.com/docker/docker/pull/8177 for more information on that.
However, volumes are used deliberately in those images for a number of reasons;
- For persistent data; volumes "outlive" the lifespan of a container; if the container "dies", the data is not lost
- Being able to "share" data (ie, --volumes-from), for example to use a one-off container to initialize the data/database. And another container to actually use or run the data(base)
- Being able to "upgrade" a container (stop the old database container, start a new one, using --volumes-from=old-container, and remove the old container)
- For performance; and this is an important reason, the layered/copy-on-write filesystem in the container has a huge performance penalty for data that's changing often, which is the case with databases.
Using a "regular" volume in stead of a bind-mounted volume could solve the permissions issue. Another solution is to chown the directory/files using the uid:gid of the database user, but if VBox shared directories are used, performance and permissions can still be tricky.

. No problem, and no harm done! my comment may be useful for people finding this issue and are new to Docker and not familiar with all aspects of volumes :smile: 
. Instead of a data-only container, you can also use a named volume;

```
create a volume for the postgres data
docker volume create --name postgres-data
and use that volume when starting the container
docker run --name some-postgres -v postgres-data:/var/lib/postgresql/data/ -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=mysecretpassword -d postgres
```

. @FrenchBen basically, each commit should be signed off. Also, the sign-off should container your real name, not your GitHub handle; see https://github.com/docker/docker/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#sign-your-work
In the main Docker repository we also usually ask contributors to "squash" their commits to logical groups. Most of the time this means that a PR contains only contains a single commit. The docker documentations has a contribution guide that describes this process; see for example this page: https://docs.docker.com/project/work-issue/
note: I'm not a maintainer in this repository, but most repositories in the Docker project follow the same rules here.
Hope this helps! Thanks a lot for your contributions, it's really appreciated :+1:

Looks like that repository does not have a :latest tag, so you will have to specify a specific tag to use; here's the steps to do so (steps below are for the offciel elasticsearch image, but the steps are similar for the image you're using):

Click on the ... button to view the image's details

Click on the Selected tag: latest to open the "tag selection" window

Click the tag / version of the image you want to run

Click the (X) to close the tag selector window

Click on the Create button to pull the image and start the container

. UPDATE: I got NFS working with docker-machine-nfs for Kitematic 0.7.6 on OSX 10.10.4
AND now experiencing 5x faster loading for Drupal's status report page, which took 20s before (without NFS) and 4s now (with NFS).
Steps to setup NFS for your docker container

Requires docker-machine version v0.3.1
   Check your version of docker-machine so it's at v0.3.1 or higher:

bash
   docker-machine --version
If the version is lower than v0.3.1, install version v0.3.1 which contains a bugfix that solves this bug: https://github.com/adlogix/docker-machine-nfs/issues/1
bash
   curl -L https://github.com/docker/machine/releases/download/v0.3.1/docker-machine_darwin-amd64 > /usr/local/bin/docker-machine &&
   sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/docker-machine
2. Install docker-machine-nfs
bash
   sudo curl -o /usr/local/bin/docker-machine-nfs https://raw.githubusercontent.com/adlogix/docker-machine-nfs/master/docker-machine-nfs.sh &&
   sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/docker-machine-nfs
3. Setup NFS sharing /Users to your docker-machine using docker-machine-nfs
   - First find the name of your docker machine with: docker-machine ls
   - If your machines name is dev: 
bash
   docker-machine-nfs dev
   - On newer versions of Kitematic I believe it's called docker-vm: 
bash
   docker-machine-nfs docker-vm
This command will: 

Notice! Comment out any conflicting shares in /etc/exports with #
Notice! If you change /etc/exports you may need to restart your docker-machine and run the following steps once again. 
   1. Modify your /etc/exports adding a line sharing /Users 
   2. Restart nfsd on your machine
   3. Configure boot2docker with a init.d script mounting /Users using NFS on startup.
   4. Restart boot2docker
4. Start a container with a volume on your newly added NFS mount.
   Here's an example using an image with ubuntu:trusty, apache, php, mysql and Drupal:
   1. SSH into your docker-machine

bash
   docker-machine ssh dev
   1. Start a container from timbrandin/drupal, change tim.brandin to your username and Projects/drupal/web to where you keep the source for your Drupal project.
bash
   docker run -d -P --name drupal -v /Users/tim.brandin/Projects/drupal/web:/var/www timbrandin/drupal
For future inspiration, check how Vagrant sets this up:
https://github.com/mitchellh/vagrant/blob/d7eaf503298014a93e1faa8da88947bc7d32ba58/plugins/hosts/bsd/cap/nfs.rb
. Here's some more development on boot2docker https://github.com/boot2docker/boot2docker/issues/581#issuecomment-127972657

. Soo, I just realized we don't need most of these features to get a CLI for managing the docker-machine, the steps to setup docker-compose for your kitematic docker-vm is as follows:
- Check the MACHINENAME of the Running docker-machine used by Kitematic:
  - docker-machine ls
- Setup the DOCKER_ environment variables (replace MACHINENAME)
  - eval $(docker-machine env MACHINENAME)
- Create your docker-compose.yml with container descriptions like above.
- Start the services
  - docker-compose up
- Other example commands:
  - docker-compose stop
  - docker-compose rm
  - docker-compose restart
And all the other commands are referenced here: https://docs.docker.com/compose/cli/#docker-host
But I can still see a benefit having a Kitematic CLI just like the Atom CLI, where one can open a Kitematic window from the terminal with or without a specified path.
What's your thoughts?
. - [x] kitematic restart – Restart the container(s) defined in the Kitematicfile.
. - [x] kitematic – Open the Kitematic application (GUI)
- [x] kitematic open – Open the Kitematic application (GUI).
- [x] kitematic list – Lists the status of container(s) managed in the Kitematicfile.
. - [x] kitematic init – Create an example docker-compose.yml.

dannc:
For those calling to merge #232 into this issue, note that the owner of this issue specifically created #232 to separate out the two related concerns.
. For those calling to merge #232 into this issue, note that the owner of this issue specifically created #232 to separate out the two related concerns.
. I believe the breakdown is like this:
210 (this issue) is now focused on providing for the ability of kitematic to interact with a private registry (i.e. one that you installed in your own local environment)
I'm guessing other hosted registries (hubs) such as Quay.io and Google Container Registry would also be covered under #210 as well.
232 Is focused on providing for the ability of kitematic to interact with a private repository.   A private repository is different than a private registry in that a private repository is just like any other image repository on DockerHub save for the fact that it's not publicly searchable and is only accessible to the organization that owns it.
These are certainly related issues but not the same issue.  I believe one could solve either of these issues separately without solving the other.
. I believe the breakdown is like this:
210 (this issue) is now focused on providing for the ability of kitematic to interact with a private registry (i.e. one that you installed in your own local environment)
I'm guessing other hosted registries (hubs) such as Quay.io and Google Container Registry would also be covered under #210 as well.
232 Is focused on providing for the ability of kitematic to interact with a private repository.   A private repository is different than a private registry in that a private repository is just like any other image repository on DockerHub save for the fact that it's not publicly searchable and is only accessible to the organization that owns it.
These are certainly related issues but not the same issue.  I believe one could solve either of these issues separately without solving the other.

fgimian:
+1 for me too, I'm all about VMware Fusion :smile:  Perhaps at a minimum, please don't install Virtualbox automatically and provide some instructions on creating the required VM in the terminal.
Should go something like this:
``` bash
Download and install docker-machine
curl -L -o /usr/local/bin/docker-machine https://github.com/docker/machine/releases/download/v0.3.0/docker-machine_darwin-amd64
Make docker-machine executable
chmod +x /usr/local/bin/docker-machine
Create the dev docker machine for use with Kitematic
docker-machine create --driver=vmwarefusion dev
Add docker-machine initialisation to bash profile
echo 'eval "$(docker-machine env dev)"' >> ~/.bash_profile 
```
I can confirm this procedure works as expected.  Right now the biggest issue is that Kitematic forces us to install Virtualbox (ewwwww ....).

. @timfallmk If you had a configuration file with a registered extension, that could act as a "one-click" mechanism for supporting a given provider. Just a thought.
. @felixphew This is what I've been advocating for a while. If I want to give an experimental or somehow different setup to a newbie to Docker, the easiest path would be to allow them to enter in the DOCKER_HOST and other DOCKER_* variables.
. @FrenchBen Making the assumption that the Docker URL was properly created seems very sensible if you are using an abstraction like Joyent's Triton. Essentially they abstract an entire data center as a single docker host thereby allowing you to connect to the Docker URL. Project Bonneville from VMWare will in all likelihood be also taking a similar approach. I've also heard from the Microsoft Docker folks that they plan on using the single host abstraction as well. Also, you can imagine a scenario where in an organization someone has provisioned a very beefy box and they give access to users to provision against it using kitematic.

As for Docker Machine, we've been living in the reality for the last couple of months where all of the pull requests were rejected and that team is in the middle of refactoring to support a driver based model. However, we are still waiting to see what that model will look like. While this all gets sorted out with Docker Machine, it would be nice to have user friendly tools like Kitematic be able to support an "advanced option". 
Regarding the ability to ssh in or regenerate the certs - platforms like Triton handle that for you or those patterns just don't apply. For example, you don't need to ssh in because there is no VM host running.
.
timfallmk:
Working on this with upcoming PR. https://github.com/timfallmk/kitematic. Will add support for all docker-machine supported backends eventually. This is the continuation of a project from DockerCon Hackathon 2015.
. Just a status update to this issue. Progress is being tracked over here and we're moving along quite well!
. @legal90 That's awesome! As we discussed for the project (and you can see in the timeline), we're probably going to stick to a limited set of drivers for the first "MVP" release in a few months, but the idea is to add support for everything machine supports eventually.
. @dekobon Are you suggesting using the machine "generic" driver for that kind of input? If so, how would you like to see the UI flow for inputting that kind of endpoint?
. @dekobon Actually the "generic" driver is just meant to cover platforms that machine doesn't specifically support. Since we want the process to be as easy as possible, we wouldn't necessarily encourage that right away. However, seeing that it would be relatively trivial to add a settings page for manual "generic" provider input, this could possibly be added to the list.
First and foremost we'd like to get the specific drivers working so people can "one click" use them.
. Thanks for the suggestions, I think the ideas are worth considering. Cloud providers will definitely be an option (Digital Ocean will probably be the only one supported in the first release).

stormbeta:
This makes it pretty difficult to recommend Kitematic right now. Putting support for creating machines with other drivers on the back-burner makes sense, but the inability to even select an pre-existing machine config, especially when Kitematic already uses docker-machine, is frustrating.
Almost every other tool related to docker I've seen allows you to define the docker config yourself, or pick from a list of visible docker-machines.. The developer console commands didn't fix it for me, but removing ~/Library/Application Support/Kitematic/Local Storage and restarting the application did. I'm not sure what the equivalent path is for Windows/Linux..

johnyzed:
In the meantime, you can do so with the command line provided by Kitematic ( docker icon in left down corner of the window). You run 'docker login', enter your credentials and after you can pull and run containers from your private repo. You can manage the running containers from the Kitematic UI.

. @domderen I've played with docker-machine.exe on Windows last week. I additionally downloaded docker.exe CLI that is also pre-built on dockerproject.com.
Assuming Chocolatey we can install VirtualBox and curl with two little steps. I have made all these steps in a good old cmd.exe shell:
cmd
λ cinst virtualbox
λ cinst curl
Then download docker-machine.exe and docker.exe 
cmd
λ curl -L -o docker-machine.exe https://github.com/docker/machine/releases/download/v0.1.0/docker-machine_windows-amd64.exe
λ curl -L -o docker.exe https://master.dockerproject.com/windows/amd64/docker.exe
Now create a VirtualBox dev machine:
cmd
λ docker-machine create -d virtualbox dev
And here comes my favorite for cmd.exe shells: Translate the unix'ish environments printed by docker-machine and set it as environment variables in a plain Windows shell:
cmd
λ for /f "tokens=2" %i in ('docker-machine env dev') do set %i
We are almost up and running. But the docker.exe (nightly build) already uses protocol version 1.18, but talking to a docker host we need version 1.17 for docker 1.5.0 hosts.
This could be done with a little trick:
cmd
λ sed -ibak -b docker.exe -e 's/1.18/1.17/g'
And now you can do something like
λ docker logs
λ docker images
Maybe this helps.

jtyberg:
I hit the 99% problem too, but my problem is not specific to Kitematic.  It's the dang Cisco VPN on Mac OS X, which tends to 1) block traffic to machines it doesn't know about, and 2) not allow modifications to the routing table while it is running.  So I could see the 'dev' machine from command line and VirtualBox, but Kitematic could not finish config.  
Once I figured out the subnet and vboxnetX machine, this fixed me:
1. stop Cisco vpn
2. sudo route -nv add -net 192.168.99 -interface vboxnet4
3. start Cisco vpn
From Kitematic side, perhaps an error stating that it could not connect to the VM would be helpful.
.

. https://github.com/kitematic/kitematic/issues/1031#issuecomment-139749024
. On windows my solution is following:
```
create a windows batch script "C:\Program Files\Docker Toolbox\kitematic_proxy.cmd" and insert following script and replace "YOUR_PROXY" with the http://host:port of your proxy

set proxy=YOUR_PROXY
SET HTTP_PROXY=%proxy%
SET HTTPS_PROXY=%proxy%
for /f %%i in ('docker-machine.exe ip default') do set DOCKER_HOST=%%i
SET NO_PROXY=%DOCKER_HOST%
set DOCKER_HOST=tcp://%DOCKER_HOST%:2376
cd Kitematic
Kitematic.exe

Btw. if you have generally an enterpise proxy between your station and internet you also shall configure this proxy in your boot2docker vm host:
Because of worng keyboard layout and problems with special key in oracle virtual box native console i connected with WinScp on my docker host using DOCKER_HOST IP login user:docker and pwd:tcuser. Then edit the profile to add proxy settings:
sudo vi /var/lib/boot2docker/profile
Press 'i' to start editing mode
export HTTP_PROXY=http://your.proxy.name:8080
export HTTPS_PROXY=http://your.proxy.name:8080
Press 'escape' and then type ':x' to save and exit the file. Now retsart your vm to make proxy active
```

. Looked a bit more into the issue and it seems to be related to the Dockerfile structure:
bash
CMD []
ENTRYPOINT ["/nodejs/bin/npm", "start"]
When creating a docker container a command is required, which is bash. 
Since you mentioned having docker installed before and if you've used this image before, how did you start it? Executing docker run -t -i google/nodejs will give you the same No command specified error.
. This is due to an incorrect/custom Dockerfile - When a docker container is created/started, a  command is usually specified to ensure that the container starts up with the proper service/command.
Most of the stuff it's bash, but it can also be a service like httpd, redis, etc. 
The problem with the image that you chose, is that the maintainer create a custom script to do, which is not within docker convention. The script should be part of the Dockerfile and then called with a command such as: sh /run.sh
Maybe in the future we can allow users to pass their own command for creation, right now it's not implemented.

If you look in the 'Preferences' of Kitematic, you'll see a new section labelled "API Settings" - If you check the box, it will look for the api.json file within the repo directory, which is at the root of the app.
The api.json file has the following structure:
- landing: These are the 'recommended' apps seen on the homepage. The icon that shows next to them is currently still being pulled from the web, but can easily be added to the repo folder
- search: This would be your search results from the docker hub, which I simply copy and pasted in. See: https://registry.hub.docker.com/v1/search?q=nginx
- info: The details of each container is store here, similar to the search above, I simply copied and pasted the results for each docker hub result. See: https://registry.hub.docker.com/v1/repositories_info/kitematic/hello-world-nginx
Kitematic's search is dynamic, so each character will trigger a search. I've only got 'nginx' as a valid search entry within the api.json file, which means that the app will trigger some errors until you finish typing 'nginx'

. Couple of things to note, which makes the above confusing to me.
1. Your vboxnet line should never change aka it's hard-coded to be 192.168.99.100
2. Your ssh command doesn't actually ssh into the container, but rather the VirtualBox that runs docker-machine, which in-turn runs the container. 
   Creating a tunnel at that level doesn't seem useful to me, since all ports should be available. (unless this is for your remote access of the port?)
With all of the above in mind, you could cut-down on a lot of work/effort by enabling port-forwarding on the VirtualBox directly using the VirtualBox manager:
http://www.howtogeek.com/122641/how-to-forward-ports-to-a-virtual-machine-and-use-it-as-a-server/

. I've actually run into something similar while trying to implement 'tag selection/prompt' during creation. 
I believe the issue is that every card is creating a listener for the tagStore change, but 1 tagStore change will trigger all cards to capture the update. 
As the number of cards grows, so does the listener, yet they all take the same action. (you can throw a debug in the update function for the ImageCard and see it being triggered over and over. 
If you'd like to discuss an ImageCard component redesign, then I'm all about it - The listener needs to be in the parent component I believe to prevent the multi-listeners.

. @shaunc it sounds like you have both boot2docker and the kitematic VM setup - You're probably looking at the previous .bashrc setup which conflicts with your current VM setup.
Here are a couple of tips to get you back on your feet:
- Edit your local .bashrc or .zshrc and comment out (add #) for each DOCKER env variable
- Confirm that your shell no longer has DOCKER like env via:
  env | grep "DOCKER"
  If any DOCKER variable exist, you can remove them via unset, like so:
bash
$ env | grep "DOCKER"
DOCKER_HOST=tcp://192.168.59.103:2376
$ unset DOCKER_HOST
$ env | grep "DOCKER"
Now to user docker with your boot2docker vm, do the following:
bash
$ eval "$(boot2docker shellinit)"
If you wanted to use the 'dev' VM as created by Kitematic:
bash
$ eval "$(docker-machine env dev)"
The issue with shared Volumes, is that by default the VM created will mount the /Users directory - You can modify this with the VirtualBox app to point to any folder you like. 
. @shaunc it sounds like you have both boot2docker and the kitematic VM setup - You're probably looking at the previous .bashrc setup which conflicts with your current VM setup.
Here are a couple of tips to get you back on your feet:
- Edit your local .bashrc or .zshrc and comment out (add #) for each DOCKER env variable
- Confirm that your shell no longer has DOCKER like env via:
  env | grep "DOCKER"
  If any DOCKER variable exist, you can remove them via unset, like so:
bash
$ env | grep "DOCKER"
DOCKER_HOST=tcp://192.168.59.103:2376
$ unset DOCKER_HOST
$ env | grep "DOCKER"
Now to user docker with your boot2docker vm, do the following:
bash
$ eval "$(boot2docker shellinit)"
If you wanted to use the 'dev' VM as created by Kitematic:
bash
$ eval "$(docker-machine env dev)"
The issue with shared Volumes, is that by default the VM created will mount the /Users directory - You can modify this with the VirtualBox app to point to any folder you like.

. The /Users volume is the default volume mounted in Virtualbox, and for most users the volumes they'll mount will be within their home directory, hence the warning.
There are 2 checks in place when mounting  a new volume:
- Is it a proper directory
- Is the directory part of the user's home path. 
The SO link will simply add, by command line, what the GUI would allow you to do, which is create a different volume mount point. 
Some flexibility should be given via Kitematic, the issue is how to determine what volumes are mounted in the VM so that things work as they should?

. For those interested in some 'pre-alpha' QA, I've put together a simple Docker Engine selector within the Kitematic preference tab:
https://github.com/TeckniX/kitematic/tree/docker-engine-selection



I've done a little bit of error detection, but still getting a bunch of warnings when updating the engine. Do use at your own risk, although the worst that can happen (I think/hope) is it will try to create a local Virtualbox with the name of your remote Docker engine. 
Background: 
- Dev - Local Virtualbox with a couple of containers
- Kitematic - Local Virtualbox manually created and used Kitematic to create new ghost container
- Staging - Digital Ocean droplet manually created via docker-machine and used Kitematic to create and run new ghost container. 
Works:
- Docker Engine selection
- Container create/start/stop/restart/delete
- Container logs
Known issues:
- Clicking the 'preview' link won't work (didn't look too much into it, maybe something with the host setup)
- Mounting of volume
I didn't try to change the Env variables but I don't see a reason for it not to work.
Feedback is welcome :)

davehun:
you can do this pretty easily using netcat:
ncat  -kl -p $MachineExternalPort --sh-exec "ncat $MacIP $MacPort"
where $MachineExternalPort is the port you want to expose
$MacIP is the ipaddress from kitematic gui ports setting
$MacPort is the port from kitematic gui ports setting
e.g.:
ncat  -4 -kl -p 8080 --sh-exec "ncat 192.168.99.100 32772"
exposed the nginx example
.
bunam:
how i correct this :
- stop Kitematic
- open VirtualBox
  -> stop the vm
  -> remove the vm (plus files)
- go to preferences / Network / hosts
  -> remove all 
- stop VirtualBox
- open VirtualBox
- go to preferences / Network / hosts
  -> add a new network
- start Kitematic
now it's working (and i can ping 192.168.99.100)
(i have complicated network setup...)

solthoth:
Hey guys, see my comment here (Issue 295). Maybe this will help?
. Hey guys, may be late to the party, but a common trend I see on issues is that if the virtual image that docker is creating in virtualbox is using 50% or more of the host's memory (RAM) then VB will not allow the instance to start up. By default I see that the ISO uses 2GB and if my box has 4GB VB sees this as an issue. Upgrading to 6GB+ fixes the issue 100% of the time for me (this is for both virtual machines and physical computers).
. I mentioned this is another thread, but I noticed that VB is actually preventing the image from running because it is using 50% or more of the host memory.
Pretty much if you computer has only 4GB of RAM and the docker image in VB needs 2GB, VB will not let you run it. Upgrading to 6GB+ does the trick, at least it did for me in all instances where I ran into this (OSX, Win7, Win8, haven't tried it on win10 yet).
.

. Hey @jeffdm, thanks :) A little update on my side about the windows port. Main points:
DONE
- I recreated the deps and reset scripts for windows to install and remove external dependencies. They are written in powershell, coz my CMD skills really suck, and I am not sure if some steps could be done in CMD without at least invoking the PS commands. I was able to loose Chocolatey dependency though, which required administrator rights, so right now the whole setup can be done without admin rights.
- I've updated the SetupStore and SetupUtil to prepare the application for windows, including the downloading and installation of VirtualBox. As mentioned before, it is done without Chocolatey, so it still might be a little shaky.
- Updated the list of directories used by the app, to proper Windows paths, so the docker and docker-machine binaries are placed on the user's directory. This might not be the best place for them, but it is a start.
- I noticed that docker-machine's boot2docker image, does not automatically share Users directory with the VM, so I created a workaround and invoke a VirtualBox command to do it manually during the VM initialization step in the SetupStore. This is a strange one though coz the regular boot2docker does that automatically. Maybe this is an issue to be raised in the docker-machine repo.
- I've rewritten a bit parts of code responsible for opening URLs or drive paths, and added an extra dependency node package called "open" which supports different platforms out of the box, so opening links and paths should now work on all platforms.
So basically now it should be possible to clone the repo, install npm deps, download app deps using the PS script, start the application in development mode, have VirtualBox installed and VM initialized, and next it should be possible to create a new container with files shared from the windows host.
AWAITS
- File sharing and selecting directories in the app is flaky on windows, it still needs some magic to work properly. It works with the directory that is attached on container creation, but it is not possible yet, to change the default dir. Also the naming for the local directory in the container's settings should be changed, coz it is called "Mac Folder", so it is not really friendly for different platforms :)
- Opening a separate terminal with docker CLI is not available yet. I haven't started working on this one, as I am not sure how to simulate the same behavior on windows, mostly because I don't fully understand what the "terminal" script file is doing.
- Application deploy in gulp file, is not ready for deploying windows version. I wanted to leave it as the last piece.
- Testing if any of my changes don't break any of the Mac functionality. Unfortunately I don't have access to Mac, so I am only testing the app on Windows, so I don't know if I didn't break anything.
- The whole windows setup needs some proper testing. I tested it so far on Windows 7 and Windows 8, but I am sure I didn't try all possible dependencies' configurations.
I think that's mostly it for now. If anyone is interested in this, the branch I am working on is available at: https://github.com/domderen/kitematic/tree/win_client
I am also thinking of send a pull request with the current changes, as a separate branch here, just to let other people participate in the work. What do you guys think about it?

. Hey, the issue was solved by my friend @KamilSzot. He found out that the usage of 
html
<script src="Main.js"></script>
in Index.html causes the issue. I changed the setup to be
html
<script src="Startup.js"></script>
and added new file Startup.js which has the following content
javascript
require('./Main');
And now the application works as expected. I will confirm that it also works on Mac, and prepare a pull request to fix the issue.

. Hey,
I've refactored the SetupUtil and especially installation step on windows, as it didn't work correctly. Now the whole setup process should work from beginning to end as expected on windows. The complete list of changes made:
- Added Resources module which provides paths to all files stored in the resources directory,
- Added docker and docker-machine binary paths to Util module, to have a single place for calling those paths,
- Added binaries directory path, to Util module, to have a single place for calling this path,
- Added another exec command, which utilizes "child_process" module, and it's "exec" command, as the "exec" used right now is deprecated,
- Refactored the Installation step in the SetupStore, and connected with that SetupUtil commands to perform copying binaries from node instead of bash commands. That way application is more cross-platform friendly,
- Added new dependencies in form of fs-extra, fs-promise and any-promise, to allow yielding of fs commands in SetupUtil.
- The setup process now works correctly on windows from the beginning to end.

- uninstall b2d.
- delete %USERPROFILE%\.boot2docker
- delete c:\program files\boot2docker for windows (if still exists)
- open virtualbox, delete boot2docker-vm with its files.
- install with the link above.
- do the first run with boot2docker start link on the Desktop or Start Menu.
- it will put you in a prompt where you can run docker ps, and it's 1.6.0-rc2.

I meet the exactly same issue as described by jschiffer and see the exactly same output as described by jeffehobbs.
Here is the way I fix the issue:
1. Close kitematic and make sure there is no process left (check activity monitor)
2. Download virtualbox from oracle.
3. After install virtualbox, launch virtualbox and I found one running instance called dev.
4. Stop that instance and remove it.
5. Re-launch kitematic and let the installation process go again. (This time it finish successfully).

giodegas:
+1
. also, having by default the port numbers corresponding to the ones in the docker file would be a nice option.
I usually started a container with:
docker run -d -p 5000:5000  -p 6000:6000/udp <image>
. I am now testing Kitematic 0.9.3. 
Changing the TCP port works. I can communicate with the internal process via TCP.
Unfortunately, changing the UDP port it does not. The internal process listening to the UDP port stops responding.
Apparently the iptables rules in the docker-VM are not properly regenerated.
The only way to use the UDP port is not changing anything, so the iptables rules do not change.
. Actually for my applications the best would be that by default the container should externally espose the port number indicated in the Dockerfile with the EXPOSE command, if they are greater that 1024 without changing to the 32768 range.
This is how Docker works on Linux without Kitematic.
Also UDP ports are not shown,in the summary, ( see #438 ) so my process is unreachable even with an unchanged ports setup.
. +1
.
ssi-praveen-marothu: Cant add same TCP & UDP ports.  If there is an existing TCP port , then adding the same port as UDP is overwriting the TCP port..

imWildCat:
Hi, @sunfuze , did you solve the problem?
In my case, it worked fine.
Just following: https://dashboard.daocloud.io/mirror

配置Docker加速器
请确认你的 Kitematic 已经启动，并执行
bash
docker-machine ssh dev
sudo sed -i "s|EXTRA_ARGS='|EXTRA_ARGS='--registry-mirror=http://<your-dao-cloud-info>.m.daocloud.io |g" /var/lib/boot2docker/profile
exit
docker-machine restart dev
.

siremurray:
Isn't this the largest blocker for using kitematic seriously? Why so little attention on this feature? Currently  there are lots of problems with host-mounted volumes on OS X, and from my understanding, using NFS fixes the most egregious one... We finally have editable ports so this seems like the only thing left before kitematic is usable.
