alexj:
Not to pile on, but I'll add a +1. I've been excited to try Docker via Kitematic, but not being able to define a volume is a hard blocker for me. I've banged my head a few times now trying to set up various Wordpress containers, but couldn't find where the files could be edited. Luckily, I found this thread. I'm excited about Kitematic, as I think I could use it to ease how I work on side projects (PHP, Python, and eventually Node). 
Sadly, I don't think there's much I can contribute to move this forward, outside of explaining my expectations as a user:
- When I load a new container, it would ideally have a volume set up with access to that container's filesystem.
- For specific containers, like one devoted to WordPress, I'd love it if Kitematic provided an easy way to go straight to that software's directory root 
- I want to be able to change the Volume's mapping of the Docker Folder - > Mac Folder, as I can with  hello-world-nginx. I should be able to do this whether or not the creator of the Creator specifically enabled it.
I'm new to Docker, so I may be asking for too much, but I thought it worth documenting.
Thanks, and keep up the great work!
.
affogato:
Why is this not possible with some containers e.g. Tomcat ?
. Why is this not possible with some containers e.g. Tomcat ?
. @zedtux To elaborate, for most of the containers that I want to use in Kitematic (e.g. official Rails, official Tomcat), it is not possible to set the Volumes or Ports parameters in the Settings tabs.

. Ok, Finally I achieve a solution to my problem and I want it to post it here. Maybe this could help other person with the same problem. I've been facing different issues but the most important one was this: Somehow the Virtualbox installation and the VMWare Workstation installation was making the Virtualbox network configuration go wrong.
So, first I uninstalled the VMWare Workstation. Then I realize the latest Windows 10 build is causing that the Virtualbox Host Only adapter, is not checking the "Virtualbox NDIS6 Bridged Networking Driver" so the default machine cannot start properly.
With these two tips, I got my kitematic working!

. I agree @FrenchBen. But I want to talk about the sudo "problem". The sudo
is only targeted to run inside the sandbox. If something odds happen and
the sudo executes on the real machine. Different alternatives:

a) Windows platform: Nothing happens.
b) MacOS X / Linux platforms: Nothing happens because it is going to
request your user's password to executes any command (in the case your user
belongs to the ones allowed to execute sudo on that machine).
Thanks!!

. I've doing several test as you commented with this result:
If I execute the followinng command:
docker run -itd --name hello1 -P -p 8888:8888 kitematic/hello-world-nginx
and then I execute a docker inspect hello1 and I can see as exposed ports both of the ports (the one that exists in the Dockerfile and the one we are specifying in the docker run command:
"ExposedPorts": {
            "80/tcp": {},
            "8888/tcp": {}
        }
And then if I execute docker stop hello1, and the docker inspect I get the same output as I get using the Kitematic (with the PR):
```
  "PortBindings": {
            "8888/tcp": [
                {
                    "HostIp": "",
                    "HostPort": "8888"
                }
            ]
        },,
```
So I have two conclusiones from here:
- I cannot reproduce the issue @FrenchBen reported: "Something else I noticed is that when adding an extra port and stopping the container, the originally exposed port-mapping is 'stuck' and will never change, when it should be released." 
- I have to find another way to discriminate the ports declared inside the dockerfile from the ones that you can add. I'm thinking about to recovering the image again and check against it, but I don't know if it too heavy operation, I'm going to give it a try!

. The problem is not the logic or the library. All of that are working fine. The problem is the event "close". On MacOS X the event application:quitting is sending on app --> before:quit but on Windows is sending on mainWindows --> close. So, it seems like at that moment the "component" to receive the event already have been close.

As a test, I change the event from close to minimize and when I minimize the window the VM shut down. So, we only have to find the right event :) 
. Mmmmm I don't find any event that suits for this situation :(. So, I'm going to go trying to find another approach...

. Done! 
. Ok, I found a way to solve the issue https://github.com/docker/kitematic/issues/1369 but I have to admit it's not a very 'pretty' solution but it has the only way I found to get it working.

The problem is this:
- On windows you are not using the before-quit event (I don't know why, but it doesn't work the same way than on Darwin system (MacOS X) ) but the close window event. 
When you receive that event and send it a new event to the app.js to close the machine if the setting is checked, but there is no time to receive the event so the action is never executed. So, the idea here is to do it two times. The first time you send the event and set a Promise to execute again the close method and then it closes.
If you find a better idea or way to get it fixed, please, go ahead!

. Thanks to @jeffdm for the assistance today in powering through the issue noted here.  In our case, this turned out to be a routing table problem that Jeff identified.  It takes a few manual steps to get around it, but it seems as though if you run a
netstat -rn
and don't have an entry for 192.168.99 for your virtualbox, you'll get a timeout, and the hanging 99% thing.  For us, this solution worked:
Quit Kitematic after the freeze
Run this at the command line:
sudo route -nv add -net 192.168.99 -interface vboxnet0
Restart Kitematic.
You shouldn't need to delete the virtual machine or kill your container.  It's a network problem at the core, not anything to do with your VirtualBox, Container or Kitematic installation.

netstat -rn
and looking for the vboxnet line.
ssh -fN -g -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o LogLevel=quiet -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -i ~/.docker/machine/machines/dev/id_rsa docker@$DOCKER_IP -L 3000:localhost:3000 $DOCKER_IP
Additionally, we might be piping in the host's IP address into the container via an ssh exec (remember our discussion yesterday?).
If the .kitematicrc was executed each time the container started, great, but its not useful enough just to have it executed when we open a terminal.
Remember, that the vast majority of our userbase is non-technical, especially when it comes to using Terminal.

I like your suggestion.  If that works, we may be in business ... can that be automated somehow at installation is the question that pops.

From: FrenchBen
Sent: ‎Wednesday‎, ‎July‎ ‎22‎, ‎2015 ‎9‎:‎18‎ ‎PM
To: kitematic/kitematic
Cc: Dennis Ruffer
SOLUTION (or high hopes)
For windows user, assume 'dev' to be 'kitematic'
Turn off your VM via the following terminal command docker-machine stop dev 
Open your VirtualBox app and go to your Preferences (app preferences, not VM settings)
Click on Network, and Host-Only Networks tab
You should see a few vboxnet entries, for each one do Click on vboxnet entry and then click on the screw-driver icon (edit)
Click on DHCP Server tab
On the selected vboxnet, check if DHCP Server is checked - if it is, check if the Server address is: 192.168.99.1 - If NOT, just click Cancel and move on to the next one.
Write down which vboxnet0, vboxnet1, vboxnet2 (however many) has the proper setting of DHCP server checked and a Server address of 192.168.99.1 and cancel out of the Preferences
Select the dev VM (windows kitematic VM)
Click Settings then Network
Adapter 2 should be a Host-Only Adapter, and change its name to be the vboxnet you noted above.
Click OK and close VirtualBox app
In your terminal run: docker-machine start dev then docker-machine regenerate-certs dev 
You can now start Kitematic and see it working :)
—

sandromello:
I think the problem may be related to the validation of SSH with the docker host, docker-machine stop validating after 3 tentatives, running docker-machine -D start dev will show the the command used for connecting with the docker host:
/usr/bin/ssh -o PasswordAuthentication=no -o IdentitiesOnly=yes -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o LogLevel=quiet -o ConnectionAttempts=3 -o ConnectTimeout=10 -i /Users/<youruser>/.docker/machine/machines/dev/id_rsa -p 51136 docker@localhost
If the docker-machine fails the SSH validation, Kitematic will not work.
The trick I think is to start the dev machine quick, restart the machine and I think it will be more fast than stopping/starting
```
docker-machine -D restart dev
After successful restart (detach from tty)
docker-machine regenerate-certs dev
```
Then start Kitematic
.

Just adding my two cents to the potential solutions. I'm running Windows 7. I uninstalled VirtualBox, restarted my computer, and let Kitematic do the install of VirtualBox for me. It now works.
.
autoferrit:
On windows 10 with virtual box 5 (letting kitematic download VB), I fixed my issue by enabling virtualization in BIOS. In windows 8/10 you can get there by clicking he power menu, holding [SHIFT] then hitting restart. Keeping [SHIFT] held until the screen changes. Then go into advanced settings and then change EUFI settings (were not changing those settings, were just getting into BIOS).
Once in BIOS just enable virtualization, then save and restart. Then it just worked.

sibprogrammer:
What is the solution or workaround for this problem?
After incorrect shutdown of notebook (due to battery) I can't download any new box using kitematic.
. There are two possible ways:
1. List of nodes with only one active node. You can switch the active node, but you see only containers of active node. Similar behaviour is used by Docker CLI.
2. Multiple active nodes in the same time. It's more complicated, but it's also more powerful. You see all containers that can belong to different nodes. 
One can start by the first way, keeping second approach in mind. Kitematic should have some screen for nodes management (list + CRUD operation). Interface should have some reference which node is currently active.
. This brings an ability to click on checkbox label instead of trying to click on checkbox itself only. In the other words "Allocate a TTY for this container" text also become clickable. It's a common pattern for apps, that not only the checkbox itself is clickable, but the whole label too.

emerick42:
I had this problem too, and solved it by simply deleting the "dev" virtual machine created by Kitematic. You will lose all your configured containers.
```
$ VBoxManage list vms
"dev" {698b51bc-ff9d-401e-a87f-957d613e6b60}
$ VBoxManage unregistervm dev --delete
```
If you have the error VBoxManage: error: The machine 'dev' is already locked by a session (or being locked or unlocked), there is another process currently accessing this VM. You may still have Kitematic running. Also you should kill the docker-manage 0.2.0 process using your task manager (which is a subprocess spawn by Kitematic to create the VM).
.

DannyvanderJagt:
I had the same error, on OS X 10.10.3, but somehow I fixed (for now). 
I googled and found this page: https://kitematic.com/docs/known-issues/. It said that I should try  docker-machine rm -f dev (in terminal) but I got these two errors:  (Kitematic app was shutdown at this point!)
ERRO[0000] Error removing machine dev: Host does not exist
FATA[0000] There was an error removing a machine. To force remove it, pass the -f option. Warning: this might leave it running on the provider.
After that I tried to second command from the page: docker-machine create -d virtualbox dev
The command tried to start the VM but it got stuck at Waiting for VM to start.... (even after 10 minutes)
After that I closed the terminal and opened the Kitematic app. Nothing had changed, still the same error. I did run to second command again and this time it worked and I got these two info statements:
NFO[0055] "dev" has been created and is now the active machine.
INFO[0055] To point your Docker client at it, run this in your shell: eval "$(docker-machine env dev)"
When I did open the Kitematic app I got the same error but I clicked the 'retry setup' button but that didn't fix it. Finally I clicked the 'Delete VM and Retry Setup' button and the app started the reinstall everything. Everthing is working now and the Kitematic app is working.
I hope this helps in fixing the bug, if there are any questions let me know.

scytacki:
I just found the bits of code that determines if Kitematic opens the webPreview or not. These might be useful if anyone starts working on this.
Kitematic looks for the first port on the container that is a 'webPort':
https://github.com/docker/kitematic/blob/e40ba41f1b2d623636241162df0b44178a685af6/src/components/ContainerDetails.react.js#L20
This list of webPorts:
https://github.com/docker/kitematic/blob/e40ba41f1b2d623636241162df0b44178a685af6/src/utils/Util.js#L215
Perhaps the list of webPorts was configurable it would address this feature request.. A work around that might work in some cases is to change which port your nginix container is using internally. Kitematic uses this set of "webPorts" to decide if it should open the web preview: https://github.com/docker/kitematic/blob/e40ba41f1b2d623636241162df0b44178a685af6/src/utils/Util.js#L215 . @npendery the snippet from file posted above is from the Kitematic source. I don't know enough about Kitematic to know if you could successfully change it locally.  I was suggesting that as a work around developers could change their own Docker and app configuration. The change is to the internal port of the container. If this internal port is not in the list above, then Kitematic will not open the web preview.
For reference, this issue was causing one of my containers to crash because it didn't expect an http GET request on its port..

Workaround, a la #261 -- add the following to .profile:
eval "$(docker-machine env dev)"
export NO_PROXY=$(echo $DOCKER_HOST | sed 's/tcp:\/\/\([^:]*\).*/\1/')
.

On Windows 7, in a bat, one can do this (with MSYS2 usr\bin in the PATH, in order to have sed):
for /f %%i in ('echo %DOCKER_HOST% ^| sed "s/tcp:\/\/\([^:]*\).*/\1/"') do set NO_PROXY=%%i

northerngit:
I've submitted a pull request to fix this issue - https://github.com/kitematic/kitematic/issues/565
In the mean time, you can manually implement the fix.
First, close Kitematic and from the OS X Terminal:
sudo curl -o /Applications/Kitematic\ \(Beta\).app/Contents/Resources/app/resources/terminal https://raw.githubusercontent.com/northerngit/kitematic/master/resources/terminal
Finally, ensure the file is executable.
sudo chmod +x /Applications/Kitematic\ \(Beta\).app/Contents/Resources/app/resources/terminal
Run Kitematic and everything should be back to normal!
. Related to issue:
https://github.com/kitematic/kitematic/issues/563

stav09:
I realise this is closed, but its still highly rated from searches. We too have been battling terrible docker pull performance from OS X (using the Docker Toolbox). 
The issue turned out to be the default network adapter provided by VirtualBox for the boot2docker guest (provisioned by docker-machine and Kitematic). Changing the network adapter type to 'PCnet-FAST III' made a huge improvement in performance (by default the type was 'Intel PRO/1000 MT Desktop').
For those with their own registries, running the latest registry:2 with docker-engine 1.9 gives even better pull performance with concurrent layer downloads.

. I've been using this nameserver for a long time, and it didn't solve the HTTP 404 problem.

I also think that if it were a DNS problem, we wouldn't get an actual HTTP status code.
Receiving an HTTP status code means that the name resolution phase of the request worked perfectly and that the request hit the server as expected. In turn, the server sent back an HTTP response saying that the requested resource was not found.

It looks like the "404 image not found" is an issue with too many redirects in VirtualBox.
HTH
. UPDATE:
Changing the GUESTS network from "NAT" to "Bridge" in Virtual Box worked as fine, although Kitematic wasn't able to startup (hanging at 99%). Switching back to "NAT" made Kitematic available again.
ORIGINAL COMMENT:
This solved the problem of having too many redirects (see console output) or getting a "404 image not found" and worked for me on OSX 10.10 with VirtualBox 4.3.28:
1. Open "Virtual Box  > Settings > Network > Host-only-networks"
2. Select "vboxnet0" and klick on the screw driver (ohhh, the irony...)
3. Select DHCP-Server and uncheck the checkbox from "Activate Server".
4. Accept with "OK".
5. Restart Kitematic.
HTH
Cordobo

briandk:
I'm able to duplicate this pretty consistently on Mac OS X 10.10.3
Steps to Reproduce (Assuming you have no existing VMs)

Open Kitematic. Let it do its initial creation of a VM
In preferences, check "Shut Down Linux VM on closing Kitematic". I'm not sure this is necessary, but it's how my Kitematic has been configured.
Quit Kitematic
Verify through VirtualBox that the VM is powered off
Launch Kitematic. It will spin up the VM. 
Verify that the VM spinup hangs at 99%, then results in the "Machine IP Could Not Be Fetched" error.

System Info

MacBook Pro (early 2011)
OS X 10.10.3
Kitematic (Beta) 0.7.3
VirtualBox 4.3.28 r100309
Virtual Machine Log
.

itsNikolay:
+1 same on mac
. I fixed it downgrading to VirtualBox 4.3
- Remove VirtualBox 5.0 (by a option in VirtualBox-5.0.dmg file)
- Download from official site and install VirtualBox 4.3
- Run Toolbox, under Customize button and skip installation of VirtualBox 5.0
Wish it'll help
.

Hello, maybe next time is worth mentioning that before you spend time developing and test it.

I still think the Kitematic / docker-machine "multi Platform / single software approach" has an advantage over the "locked in" native versions.

Here's the timeline as I see it. That's my point of view and may be totally wrong, since I don't have any knowledge about the real timeline and the people involved. 
We probably started our approach to include hyper-v into Kitematic at about the same time frame as Docker created D4W. ... D4W concepts may be several months earlier. 
January
The "unikernal guys" joined docker in January 
February
Docker moved closer to alpine in February. .. which (btw) caused some confusion in the "ubuntu camp"
(fast forward May 2016: those groups seem to be responsible for a big part of the implementation
March
This PR started 14th March. 
The first public post in the D4W discussion forum was created on 17th March.
Docker for Mac and Windows beta was announced at the end of March. ... I did request an invitation the same day.
April
April 3rd I got my link to test the beta. D4W was far away, from what it is now. ... 
May 9th 
This PR got the "postpone" label, which for me is very close to "no". In the sense of: "No" is temporary and "Yes" is forever ;)
May 10th
Kitematic 0.10.3 is the first version that supports Docker for Widnows natively. 
You may find a "Docker for Windows" link here: https://forums.docker.com/t/docker-for-windows-beta-invites/9234/6 ...  I don't know if it still works as intended.

I think the ubuntu base images are way to big to be convenient. I use busybox, debian or now alpine. They still need minutes to be initialized the first time. In my opinion pulling gigabytes of images is just wasted time and super boring. 
. I think, docker for Mac and Windows is a different approach. IMO it's just a tighter integration into the native OS. In the video there is not much UI. Windows users will need a lot of UI and no CLI at all! Command line freaks the hell out of us ;). 
For windows you'll need hyper-v atm. ... Which is a good thing for me. I currently hacked kitematic to support hyper-v instead of vbox. .. You can have only one active hyper visor in windows. So if hyper-v is active vbox can't work anymore. .... but
Probably the minority of windows users have OS versions installed, that support hyper-v. So vbox imo will always be a fast and cheap option for the masses. 
I think there is much need for a program like kitematic for beginners. You basically have a "One click" experience, with a fast success. It abstracts all the glitches away, which is good at the beginning. ... 
After a while, as you'll start to dig deeper. You'll need more fine grained control, where the CLI comes back in. .. Or a much improved (may be rewritten) future Kitematic. eg: Kitematic is english only atm. ...

childnode:
:information_desk_person: partial Workaround:
1. Clone your boot2docker machine to "kitematic" if available ;)
2. do
   - copy ssh keys from %USERPROFILE%\.ssh\id_boot2docker to %USERPROFILE%\.docker\machine\machines\kitematic\id_rsa
   - copy keys / certs from %USERPROFILE%\.boot2docker\certs\boot2docker-vm to %USERPROFILE%\.docker\machine\certs
   - make a second copy of them to %USERPROFILE%\.docker\machine\machines\kitematic
   - ~~delete corrupt machine config: %USERPROFILE%\.docker\machine\machines\kitematic~~
3. fix corrupt config: change ssh port from 0 to what is the forwarding local port for your NAT device in the cloned virtualBox device
   (on clone, virtualbox will auto-remap this from boot2docker default 2022 to a new highport)
4. add the new docker-VM ip to Windows NO_PROXY: here set NO_PROXY=%NO_PROXY%,192.168.59.103
5. "retry setup"
you might test the connection yourself by
%LOCALAPPDATA%\Kitematic\app-0.7.0\resources\resources>docker-machine ssh kitematic
=> :warning: still not working, it's rebooting  then hanging up at 99%.
=> :x:  Kitematic: Cannot connect to Docker engine. Either VM is not responding or the connection may be blocked (VPN or PROXY) connect ETIMEDOUT 192.168.59:103:2376
if on console with working env you get
$ docker -H 192.168.59.103:2376 ps you might see the cause, typically auth failure on proxy
=>  you might add your HTTP_PROXY and NO_PROXY settings in the VM yourself at /var/lib/boot2docker/profile, don't miss to add the local IPs from the vm and your client machine to NO_PROXY to prevent proxy connection tries on local resources. Else you might get errors like "can't connect to docker hub"

arneluehrs:
Well, in this setting the problem is also fixable by explicitly setting http_proxy, https_proxy nad above all the no_proxy environment variable (tested with @ojacques setup)  The problem then moves to the next step. Inside the docker engine host we need to set the proxy again.
And that seems indeed like the problem mentioned in the docker-machine.
So you can use the docker-machine commands to get to your image.
docker-machine ssh kitematic
and by adding the env variables to /var/lib/docker/profile you get back to a fully working setup.
This however is unsatisfactory as you need to redo that setup at every time you destroy your docker engine (i.e. you rebuild your VM).
So passing the env variables from the hosting environment down to the Docker host machine is the best way to go.
It is to be tested if it would have to be propagated even furter into the containers (normally yes) or if that can be handled by an -e option in the docker run of the container.
Our internal writeup for users is the following:
Configuring/ using kitematic alpha
Download and install kiteamatic alpha for windows https://go.docker.com/.....
Install and run kitematic
open a Docker CLI window (see bottom left of kitematic window
enter docker host:   docker-machine ssh kitematic
Edit via sudo  /var/lib/boot2docker/profile to read as following:
export http_proxy=http://:8080 
export https_proxy=http://:8080 
export no_proxy=kitematic,127.0.0.1,localhost
EXTRA_ARGS=' --label provider=virtualbox  --insecure-registry :443 ' 
CACERT=/var/lib/boot2docker/ca.pem 
DOCKER_HOST='-H tcp://0.0.0.0:2376' 
DOCKER_STORAGE=aufs 
DOCKER_TLS=auto 
SERVERKEY=/var/lib/boot2docker/server-key.pem 
SERVERCERT=/var/lib/boot2docker/server.pem
Save the file
exit the docker host (exit)
restart the docker-machine
docker-machine stop kitematic
docker-machine start kitematic
set-item env:http_proxy http://:8080
set-item env:https_proxy http://:8080
Go back to the kitematic UI and try your luck with an official busybox image. It should download now...
docker pull busybox
Launch Kitematic Gui
.\kitematic
.

ambled:
I'm not sure if this is the/a cause or needs to be a separate issue:
my boot2docker.iso shows as:
Linux dev 4.0.7-boot2docker #1 SMP Wed Jul 15 00:01:41 UTC 2015 x86_64 GNU/Linux
I've not only had this DNS issue, but it keeps reoccurring every 12 hours.
I discovered that the dhcp configurations in this iso has some issues:
* when the dhcp reservation (which might be low) expires, the /etc/resolv.conf gets rewritten by udhcpc
* udhcpc uses  /usr/share/udhcpc/default.script
* default.script either clobbers and rewrites only the dhcp response, or ...
* you can override the DHCP list by creating a 'dns' environment variable entry in default.script as a whitespace seperated list of ips. However, default.script handles this case poorly and appends the configured nameservers every time the lease expires
the end result is that as configured (at least with the responses I get from my DHCP server) the VM might be working initially for people, then stops working because of a pause/resume machine event, network reconfiguration or just a DHCP lease timeout.
Since all of these events can trigger the problem and DHCP leases can vary widely between environments, it might be complicating efforts to find the root cause.
As this issue seems to come from upstream on the boot2docker.iso, my current workaround seems to be holding (bypassing the NAT DNS and forwarding to the host).
docker-machine stop dev
VBoxManage modifyvm dev --natdnsproxy1 off --natdnshostresolver1 off
docker-machine start dev
There are lots of ways to address this, not sure which makes the most sense. I think I'd like the equivalent of the resovlconf framework with head and tail entries.  Improving the udhcpc script to look for /etc/resolvconf/resolvconf.d  or pull settings from /etc/default seems like a possible path, however that still ends up requiring manually fiddling files on the virtual host machine.

My current persistence hack, after starting the vm (but from OSX command line):
- Create docker machine boot patch script
  $ cat ~/.docker/bootsync.sh
#!/bin/sh
  sed -i '/if \[ -n \"\$dns\" \]/a     dns=\"$dns 8.8.8.8\"' /usr/share/udhcpc/default.script
  #sed -i '/if \[ -n \"\$domain\" \]/a     domain=\"$domain dev\"' /usr/share/udhcpc/default.script
- Inject boot script into persistent location on virtual host image
  $ docker-machine scp ~/.docker/bootsync.sh dev:/mnt/sda1/var/lib/boot2docker/bootsync.sh
- Execute script to patch current ephemeral default.script. Or do a docker-machine restart
  $ docker-machine ssh dev sudo sh /mnt/sda1/var/lib/boot2docker/bootsynch.sh

tylerhjones:
The problem is not the DNS you have, it is the packet return size. Im guessing for 8.8.8.8 the return size is less than 512 bytes. So the UDP packet is forwarded from the vm running on your machine to the host machine. When the DNS returns a packet size over 512 DNS will fall over to TCP, which it looks like the vm is not forwarding to your host machine and thus it cannot resolve.
Notice the "tcp" in "dial tcp: lookup index.docker.io", that indicates to me this is the problem.
The "192.168" private address hints to me that this is the private network between your vm and the container.
.
Deepak-Poojari: Your docker host may be behind the proxy. Set the proxy in /etc/sysconfig/docker. That should fix the problem..
st0ne-dot-at:
Hi all,
i had similar issues with occasionally occuring lookup outages. I've tracked the issue down to the libc library of the gitea docker image.
The image uses the libc.musl-x86_64.so.1 libc library ... which uses an unusual resolve mechanism. It 
queries the nameservers in parallel (see docker-alpine). This behavior differs from the glibc resolving behavior. The glibc resolver uses always the first entry.
In my case i had a local dns server in the first line, followed by external dns servers. This leaded to resolving errors, because only the local dns server was able to resolve the ip address of the db container.
May that helps.
.

This is a boot2docker issue. It usually occurs whenever the boot2docker VM is restarted. There's no official fix for it yet, but you can work around the issue by adding the following file to your boot2docker VM:
/var/lib/boot2docker/profile
bash
waitForEth1() {
  COUNT=0
  until ip a show eth1 | grep -q UP
  do
    [ $((COUNT++)) -gt 60 ] && break || sleep 1
  done
  sleep 1
}
waitForEth1

In regards to the missing directory, I'm not sure why it's not on your system. /var/lib/boot2docker is a symbolic link. This is what /var/lib looks like on my boot2docker VM:

lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root          29 Jun 29 13:39 boot2docker -> /mnt/sda1/var/lib/boot2docker/
lrwxrwxrwx    1 root     root          24 Jun 29 13:39 docker -> /mnt/sda1/var/lib/docker/
drwxr-xr-x    4 root     root         160 Jun 29 13:39 nfs/

phersh:
I think the problem is in the ./resources/terminal script which is called when "DOCKER CLI" button is pressed. Currently that script assumes the use of bash shell and is not compatible with zsh. zsh is very popular shell at least on OS X. I am submitting a pull request which makes the script compatible with both zsh and bash.
. The terminal script doesn't correctly set the path. If you already have the path to the command line tools set from another installation of docker, or if you manually edited your bashrc or zshrc to add the path, then you won't see the error. You can easily check by removing the command line tools location from your path and then running kitematic and CL tools button.

ddcruver:
Just wanted to additional requirements that you may want to consider, some are related to each other and/or might already be considered.
1.) Installation - Ability to not install VirtualBox and/or not have a local instance.
2.) Allow local engine that is not VirtualBox (at Install? or after the fact)
3.) VMware Workstation Support as a Docker Engine VM
4.) Support for Storing TLS Certs for Authentication (In App)
5.) Support for using Window Certificate Store to get TLS Certs
6.) Integration with Pageant (of Putty) 
Additional Remarks:
3.) This may be out of scope of the kitematic sub-project.
4 and 5.)
In the case of 4 and 5 only one would be really needed I am favoring 5 for simplicity reasons, no GUI needs to be made and adding certificates to store is documented already.  Currently common applications like Internet Explorer and Chrome both share this store on windows.
6.) This may not be possible as I don't believe Docker supports OpenSSL Private Public Key Authentication.

atbrew:
It will grow up to the maximum specified, which is 20G (for the Kitematic docker-machine default).
I did try to work around this with docker-machine creating the box for me before launching kitematic, with mixed sucess. I needed to use the docker-machine that was bundled with KiteMatic (as opposed to the one I have installed separate to kitematic) to create the machine manually. After this Kitematic was able to use that virtual machine
# create an alias to kitematics docker-machine
alias dm='/Applications/Kitematic\ (Beta).app/Contents/Resources/resources/docker-machine'
# create the dev docker machine with a 40G (dynamically grown) disk
dm create -d virtualbox --virtualbox-disk-size "40000" dev
.
leebenson:
That's the Goal of kitematic - Although going over 20GB in containers/images I feel isn't the typical setup.  Out of curiosity, how many containers/images do you have?

I blitzed through 20GB in the first day of using Kitematic. My dev environment re-builds huge caches (about 3GB each), and each new build is versioned. It's not uncommon for my team to go through several versions a day. That's on top of the 10-15GB of extra tooling we bring in through 5-7 different Dockerfiles via Docker Compose.
We delete all active containers and kill any images, but the artefacts left behind by switching versions all the time easily pushes us over this number. SSH'ing into the box and manually culling is arduous and doesn't always prevent the 'no space left on device' warnings.
Applying a 20GB limit is too opinionated and arbitrary and clearly doesn't work for all users, hence this issue.
. @FrenchBen Defaults are fine if there's an easy way to change them. Is there someone I could look for instructions? thanks.
. @FrenchBen thanks. I understand this is VirtualBox's problem, but since Kitematic is the front-facing entry point to OS X Docker (and docker-machine in turn), it'd be nice if one of the Docker tools took ownership of the underlying boot2docker set-up / machine resizing with a simpler GUI, or at least some kind of CLI flag to abstract it.
I think it'd go a long way to support Docker's goal of making Docker Toolbox a friendly front-end.
Sorry if I'm airing opinions in the wrong place. It's just because Kitematic is the first layer we use.
.

grempe:
If this PR is stable and works against both the older and newer iTerm2 I would vote for applying it now.  It may be entirely possible that iTerm2 will sit in beta for many months before a new 'stable' version is released. This beta was a surprise release after 18 months of development.
http://iterm2.com/version3.html
In the meantime we all get stuck with ugly little terminal windows.  Please handle both old and new versions of iTerm2.  You can remove the dual handler code later.
. Please also note that the developer of iTerm2 has provided sample code for supporting simultaneously supporting the AppleScript of both the old and the new versions here:
http://iterm2.com/applescript.html
. I copied the terminal file as found here:
https://github.com/kudos/kitematic/blob/iterm2point9/resources/terminal
and it worked like a charm for me.  I am using iTerm2 version Build 2.9.20160206
Kudos to @kudos 
.

http://ux.stackexchange.com/questions/63527/usability-of-vertical-split-bar-to-resize-splitted-view

. Hi 
I haven't been using Kitematic for a while now, but this problem doesn't seem to have been solved.
I didn't go through all the posts I see, but I noticed something I didn't notice before:
When Atom helper is taking all the processor time you can easily stop and restart the problem by opening and closing the Kitematic window. :-)
To reproduce my working condition:
I work with DockerKitematic 0.8.3; built with Docker Enging 1.8.1 and Docker Machine 0.4.1
VB 5.0.2 and Electron 0.27.2
I started only one docker (moul/drupal) but the Atom Helper heating up happens as well with other dockers.
Funny thing is, you can have several repeatable conditions with different processor use:
1 Kitematic open showing the log of this docker: Energy impact 378
2 Kitematic open showing the port config of this docker: Energy impact 187
3 Kitematic open showing the log of this docker: Energy impact 378
4 Kitematic again open, on home -> showing log -> 378
BUT THEN: is I put my Kitematic window behind an other window (of an other app) ->Energy impact 0 !!
IF I UNHIDE 1 pixel of the Kinematic app keeping it in the back -> Boom ->378
HIDING every pixel again -> impact 0
(of course in all cases, at least one docker must be running)
Seems the app is rewriting the screen buffer somewhere with an interval that is way too short...
I hope this helps!
Hereby a number of screenshots





Kind regards.
Erwin
.
ruurd:
Having similar problems with Kitematic in the docker for osx beta. I'm suspeccting that the green animated icon is the culprit here. Is it possible to NOT use something animated for a running container?
. If you look closely at the left column in Kitematic you see that when a container is running the then green colored icon has a wave in it that is slowly animated. Even starting a single container leads to a steady ~30% cpu use at my machine as long as Kitematic is displayed on screen. If minimized, cpu use drops to an acceptable level. If restored again, cpu use is up again. Stop all containers and no green icons are visible cpu use goes back to normal again.
. Kitematic covered by iTerm

Kitematic minimized

Kitematic exposed running multiple containers

Kitematic running a single container

Kitematic running nothing

. No spike. Just +- 25-30% CPU if a single green icon is visible with idle container(s) running

jhaumont:
@mchiang0610 
It works for me with the lastest version. I ve a corporate proxy and no problem to launch kitematic.
But http_proxy and https_proxy are not set in my window env variables
Still have a problem when I m on the Kitematic GUI, I can't browse dockerHub or logging to my dockerHub account.
I have to do this procedure : 
- On Kinematic GUI, open a DockerCli window
- Close Kinematic CUI
- In powershell DockerCli window, set the following parameters : 
  - set-item env:http_proxy http://:8080
  - set-item env:https_proxy http://:8080
  - set-item env:no_proxy .company,.sock,localhost,127.0.0.1,::1,192.168.99.100
- Launch Kitematic Gui (go to the install directory) : 
  - .\Kitematic.exe
After that, I can browse docker containers :)
I think a feature request to add proxy settings in the settings menu of Kitematic can be usefull !
PS : This procedure come from this post : 
https://github.com/kitematic/kitematic/issues/685

- OS X 10.10.4
- boot2docker was installed.
- Then, without touching boot2docker, I installed Docker Toolbox 1.8.1.
- Machine dev was automatically created (previous VM was called default - named by boot2docker without my intervention, so the name boot2docker-vm that is mentioned in the docs is news to me).
- Machine dev was made "active".
- Env vars set OK with eval "$(docker-machine env dev)".

``` bash

Error response from daemon: client is newer than server (client API version: 1.20, server API version: 1.19)

Stopping machine to do the upgrade...

rockaja:
Temp fix for windows
client is newer than server (client API version: 1.20, server API version: 1.19) 
If you have the above  error message when you try to run docker on windows after installing docker-toolbox try this
Right click on the default server on virtual-box and select power off now go to 
https://github.com/boot2docker/boot2docker/releases 
and download the latest boot2docker iso
Now back to your machine, go to 
C:\Users.docker\machine\machines\default and replace the boot2docker.iso with the new one
The old one is ~27MB the new one is ~29MB
Then go back to Virtualbox default server and click on start.. This will force it to use the new iso image when booting up
This is a temp fix because if you shutdown and restart the default virtual server it will download the 27MB iso image again and you will loose the one you downloaded.
As noted this is a quick fix - and there should be a better way to persist the latest iso image.
Thanks
.

@FrenchBen I have resolved the issue. Here are the steps I used for OS X10.10.5 and VirtualBox 5.0.3 test release:
1. Uninstall any existing VirtualBox using the official Uninstall.tool
   You may need to reboot if certain kext files are not properly unloaded. I had to.
2. Run Kitematic reset script (as mentioned earlier)
3. Install VirtualBox 5.03 testing (link here)
4. Install Docker Toolbox
After these steps I was able to launch Kitematic and login to the Docker Hub, and verified that I was able to pull and run an image from the registry.

sh
  # set Docker environment variables using docker-machine
  test -f /usr/local/bin/docker-machine && eval $($_ env default)

uh. This is definitely related to Kitematic and not a docker/dockerfile specific problem. If i build the image manually on a linux machine (without using kitematic) everything works fine, its a fairly simple command.

wkoszek:
My understanding is that this is a different problem: Wordpress has a dependency, but Kitematic can't figure it out, so it errors out. Since Wordpress needs MySQL, on "Create", I'd expect Kitematic to ask me to install MySQL automatically and get these environment variables right.
In other words: Kitematic experience isn't complete if I have to be jumping back and forth between GUI and the command line to bootstrap it.
. Just letting you know about my experiences: Wordpress was a random choice of something I knew has dependencies.
I think the summary of the problem is: Kitematic just wraps Docker command line, not Docker Compose, and thus it's unaware of further needs of the container.
Would be nice to see us wrapping and presenting Docker Compose recipes instead of raw images.
. Talked to @FrenchBen and we discussed technical problems. Looks like there's no good way to solve this problem with Docker metadata, so I guess it makes sense to close this as "never fix"
. .
. This looks like a problem in Kitematic. If there's any requirement to get stuff set, I'd expect Kitematic to ask me to input it. Could we throw a popup so that I can configure this environment variable at container setup time (maybe after hitting "Create")?
If not, can you at least throw a warning "footer" with a link to documentation of the image?
. @FrenchBen so basically you're saying you don't know upfront what to ask for? I've looked at the mysql Dockerfile and I feel like you don't have enough metadata?
I like the car analogy :-) But to me it's like I ordered a TV and it got shipped to me, but without necessary cables.
. We talked about adding a help screen to overcome the problems with the parameters. Similar to other issues: Docker doesn't provide enough metadata to give the UI enough feedback on what to ask for, so I guess we should close it as "never fixed"
. It might be since I migrated from Boot2Docker? I had to docker-machine rm default; docker-machine rm dev, redownload everything and the new machine seems to have dynamically resized drive and it works.

dayelostraco:
If you'd prefer not to have to run the eval statement mentioned by @FrenchBen and @costimuraru on every terminal session, you could update you bash_profile with the following:
Docker
eval "$(docker-machine env default)"
Be sure to restart the terminal session or run source for the changes to take effect.

But somehow, it does seem to be configured correctly:
```

export http_proxy="http://127.0.0.1:3129/"

```
But somehow, the launched instance doesn't use those parameters:
npiguet@npi-desktop:/etc/docker/certs.d/docker.io$ ps -eaf | grep docker
root      2559     1  0 déc21 ?       00:00:18 /usr/bin/docker daemon -H fd://
. Well apparently, the issue is that the docker package for ubuntu 15.10 is broken out of the box (as in the server is not setup to listen to the port that the client is told to connect to). Actually, the sysvinit configuration is correct, but ubuntu uses systemd and the packaged systemd config for docker just doesn't work.
For other people that have the same problem, a solution for that can be found at: http://nknu.net/how-to-configure-docker-on-ubuntu-15-04/
.

plusmancn:
Ref: https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/17645
run
service docker status
show
Main PID: 660 (docker)
   CGroup: /system.slice/docker.service
           └─660 /usr/bin/docker daemon -H fd://
So, if the docker user doesn't belong to the same group as login user, it is not able to access to docker daemon service.  
Solution，Add user docker to the same group as login user
sudo usermod -aG docker <username>
IMPORTANT log out and back in to take effect
.

fmvilas:
Actually this could be included inside Advanced tab. This way the configuration is per container, behind the scenes it will set the SHELL environment variable and you can have a UI piece to configure it instead of having to explain/document.. You're right but I had to come to this issue to understand that what I needed is to add a new env var. I was suggesting to have a UI piece that sets the right env var with the right value (a list of most commonly used shell binaries and optionally a way to set a custom one). Not sure I'm explaining myself properly :smile:. Got it. It's not an easy to solve problem. I see two issues here:

The user not knowing bash (and others) are not always included in containers.
The user not knowing that what she has to do is to set SHELL env var.

The first one you figure out when the error happens. The second one I think could just be mitigated like this:
[ ] Use custom shell   <- A checkbox with label
===== <- a text input here that is enabled when you click on Use custom shell option above
Warning: Make sure this shell is included in your container.   <- A label here.
Once you know the first problem you will try to find something in configuration and if you find that piece it will be easier to understand. This could be complemented with an explanation text on the environment variables section, explaining that setting SHELL var will work.
Another option coming to my mind is adding a dropdown to the Exec button with the option: "Use a custom shell" and in the dialog explain the user needs to make sure the "custom shell" exists in the container.
They are not perfect but it could give some clues to the user.
P.S.: Sorry for the long text, hope it can help in some way 😊 . @FrenchBen I'll be happy to submit a PR after we agree on a solution hehe.

The checkbox for your custom shell will essentially be an ENV var, correct?

Yes.

I don't understand this question. My point here was just to add an ENV var and of course it will be also visible on the ENV vars section.

How do you deal with images that define an ENV var of SHELL?

That's a good point. I'm not sure if we can have a way to know it beforehand but, if not, we can just add a message as a "warning" label when setting your own shell. As a first iteration is fine and then it might be improved if possible..

. Just a note for the future readers. It looks to me that KVM (Kernel) virtualisation, called sometimes paravirtualization, does not support (is not) VT-X, whereas HVM (Hardware-assisted) virtualisation is called VT-X for Intel x86 family (AMD-V for amds). 
KVM is the normal. HVM demands the host system (XEN Hypervisor for instance) to be build in a certain manner to allow special access for the virtual machine to the underlying hardware.

kriscarle:
In case it helps, my issue (due to an unlucky coincidence) was that the network I'm sitting at was already using using the 192.168.99.x subnet that docker-machine uses by default for the virtualbox host-only network.  
The main clue was that I was unable to ping/ssh to the IP provided by docker. I solved it by:
1) running docker-machine rm default
2) Going into VirtualBox preferences and removing the host-only network. 
3) running docker-machine create --driver virtualbox --virtualbox-hostonly-cidr "192.168.59.1/24" default
. For the IP issue, also see #638 and docker/machine/issues/1573
The IP is hardcoded in the virtualbox setup here https://github.com/docker/machine/blob/c10962320729a8d436eb09ce9aaae1f4bdd7d0ad/drivers/virtualbox/virtualbox.go#L31
Would it be possible to have it check if 192.168.99.1 is present on the network then try a different IP, or maybe just use a different default since 192.168.99.x seems to be relatively popular? 
.

. @FrenchBen, unfortunately the situation remains the same after the update.
. Aww yiss, I cracked it! It was actually a problem where Windows had somehow turned off the NDIS6 bridged driver entry for my VBox Host-only network adapter. This StackOverflow answer has the details on how to fix it:
1. Open network center
2. Click "Change adapter settings"
3. Right click your Virtualbox host-only adapter and select Properties
4. Enable "Virtualbox NDIS6 Bridget Networking Driver"
So I'm golden and Kitematic works again :+1:
. To be clear, this prevents any vbox vm using a host-only adapter from working, not just Kitematic, so I'd say it's a vbox bug in that they don't validate that setting. Dunno if they even can though.

first of all {val.display} will always produce empty string after changes were made to allow user to edit port manually.
thing that was previously called "access url" is available in scope, however it is just simple combination of http://{ip}:{port}, so it will lead to something like "http://192.168.99.100:5432" which doesn't make any sense for user because there is no web server at this address. the idea of detecting web UI is user-friendly, however we need smart solution here to make it useful. i was thinking about loading this "access url" with http client and check if there some http answer or not. however this feature requires some design and analysis from UX prospective.

buddhafinger:
Just posted this on another thread regarding Docker Toolbox - It might help with this problem also.
I was experiencing similar issues:
My setup:
OS X 10.10.5
VirtualBox 5.0.4
Docker Toolbox 1.8.2c
Problems experienced:
Quickstart terminal launches default instance and then prompts for password.
Same D-Bus not installed errors in the log.
Unable to successfully recreate the default instance using Kitematic (failed as unable to connect to instance)
Resolution:
Deleted the default docker machine and all associated files.
Deleted 'Host only Networks' in Virtualbox - Preferences - Network - Host Only Network.
Launch Kitematic and let it create the default VM (successfully)
Launch Docker QuickStart terminal and it now works without any problems.
I can now launch docker instances via docker quick start term and use kitematic without any issues.
I got the solution from the link below, I assume it was caused by a conflict with an existing host only network. It's also worth noting the D-Bus error still exists, however things seem to be working fine.
.

mrumpf:
The issue is the corporate VPN solution on our notebooks (I work for the same company). The VPN client allows no other network adapters than a defined set:
- LAN
- WLAN
- VPN Adapter
- Host-Only Network 169.254.0.20/16 (This adapter gets configured with a special package, that our corporate software distrubution tool provides for installation on employee notebooks)
If you create another host-only network adapter, the VPN client starts complaining about the new/unknown network adapter until you turn it off :(
Therefore we need to set the parameter --virtualbox-hostonly-cidr "169.254.0.20/16" to the docker-machine create command.
It would be great if you could provide a config file, maybe ~/.docker/kitematicrc, where a user can define parameters that are used by kitematic for creating the virtual machine. Or you display any existing docker-machine instances in kitematic without creating a default one.
Another issue is the corporate HTTP proxy which the only way to acces resources from the internet.
A docker-machine command that works in out environment looks like this:
docker-machine create \
    --driver virtualbox \
    --engine-env HTTP_PROXY=http://10.206.246.20:8080 \
    --engine-env HTTPS_PROXY=http://10.206.246.20:8080 \
    --virtualbox-hostonly-cidr "169.254.0.20/16" \
    dev
. Does this also include the --engine-env *_PROXY to configure the HTTP proxy inside the Docker Machine virtual machine? Without the HTTPS_PROXY, HTTP_PROXY, and NO_PROXY parameters it is not possible in our corporate environment to connect to Docker Hub.
.
tarapara:
@FrenchBen thanks for your support! We made it working through following trick:
1. Create the default vm manually by supplying these additional required parameters like: --virtualbox-hostonly-cidr and --engine-env *_PROXY.
2.  Start Kitematic.exe from Git Bash after exporting the proxy settings:
export https_proxy=[IP]:[PORT]
export http_proxy=[IP]:[PORT]
.

kidhasmoxy:
We have several users that have reported a similar issue on different versions of OS X, with the latest Kitematic install from the Docker Toolbox (myself included.) The fix that seems to work best is to disable the option that tells Kitematic to shutdown the VM when quiting, then just restarting Kitematic. 
It seems to happen most often when Kitematic is starting the VM, but a quick relaunch fixes it for most. Some users have just taken to using the Quickstart terminal, since the Containers show up just fine there.

Is the docker daemon running on this host? error occurs reproducibly when using sudo docker to execute commands. Make sure you're not using sudo. petergdoyle:
I am yet to be convinced of the benefit of using Docker-Machine(/Boot2Docker) for OS X and this is one of those very issues. I would rather (might as well) create my own Linux VM with Virtualbox and Vagrant and start that (or just keep it running all the time) and have a real linux-docker environment as Mac OS X shell brings along its own set of inconveniences if you plan on running shell scripts and utilities that are to be compatible with both OS X and Linux (at least the distros I use) - but that is a different discussion but for references some of the differences are outlined here. I would rather not have to have two versions of my automation and execution scripts. Why OS X doesn't just support CGROUPS natively is another discussion as well; then this kluge (Docker-Machine/Boot2Docker) would be unnecessary. 
If anyone is interested you can take a look at how to roll-your-own docker machine with Vagrant and VirtualBox - Virtualbox already got installed anyway if you got this far. You don't have to pull my Vagrant CentOS image you can pull or create your own Vagrant Box - setup

yjimk:
For anyone who has a similar problem with docker on OSX, I was able to find the solution here: http://blog.petehouston.com/2016/03/05/run-docker-properly-on-mac-os-x/
To paraphrase
docker-machine create --driver virtualbox default
docker-machine env default
eval $(docker-machine env default)
Was then able to run Docker commands in OSX
.

xu-dan:
I got the similar issue after putting my mac into sleep. And I am able to fix it by following the suggestions from https://github.com/docker/machine/issues/2136.
Basically, I removed all host only interfaces from my virtualbox (VirtualBox => Preferences => Network => Host-only networks), then delete ~/.docker/ folder and exit virtualbox.
After that, I am able to successfully create and connect to the 'default' docker machine again.
.

Dulani:
I managed to get past this issue chaining together many of the suggestions above (OS X 10.10, Docker 1.11.2, docker-machine 0.7.0, & vbox 5.0.20).  The machine is new and the docker packages were a fresh install.
This seems to be the simplest test that it is broken: 
$ docker info
Cannot connect to the Docker daemon. Is the docker daemon running on this host?
So, I did this:
$ docker-machine regenerate-certs
And then this: 
$ sudo ifconfig vboxnet8 down && sudo ifconfig vboxnet8
And then this: 
$ eval "$(docker-machine env default)"
And finally got this:
$ docker info
Containers: 0
Running: 0
Paused: 0
Stopped: 0... yada yada yada
Then all the other docker daemon and TLS related errors appear to have gone away (and Kitematic is working now too).

. So I fooled around with VBoxManage / VBoxControl. Here's what I got so far.
Mounting all shares within guest box can be done with something like this:
VBoxControl --nologo sharedfolder list | grep "-" | awk '{print $3}' | xargs -r mkdir {} && mount -t vboxsf -o gid=50,uid=1000 {} /{}
This works almost ok, except for 2 problems.
1. it also creates a "{}" folder. If someone can help fix that, it would be great.
2. it doesn't handle nested folders.
Then I tried running this from host machine, but stumbled upon following:
VBoxManage guestcontrol {599eb0ba-9800-428f-9bf3-6d05b92e0d2e} run "which awk"
VBoxManage: error: The specified user was not able to logon on guest
VBoxManage: error: Details: code VBOX_E_IPRT_ERROR (0x80bb0005), component GuestSessionWrap, interface IGuestSession, callee nsISupports
VBoxManage: error: Context: "WaitForArray(ComSafeArrayAsInParam(aSessionWaitFlags), 30 * 1000, &enmWaitResult)" at line 938 of file VBoxManageGuestCtrl.cpp
If someone could help me fix these issues I think I would be able to make a bash script to fix automount.
It is also possible to get list of all shares using VBoxManage, but it doesn't change anything that much since one needs to run a command from host machine to mount them too.
. > Are you running it inside the Boot2docker machine on the Virtualbox?
Yes, however I'm not yet sure the mount works properly. {} folder prevents from further testing

mkdir -p

live and learn :)
Any idea on how to run this within guest machine from the host?
. So more fooling around and here's what I got.
Run from host computer:
for i in $(VBoxManage list vms | grep "\"default\"" | awk '{print $2}' | xargs VBoxManage showvminfo --details --machinereadable | grep SharedFolderNameMachineMapping | awk -F '"' '{print $2}'); do docker-machine ssh default "sudo mkdir -p /$i; sudo mount -t vboxsf -o gid=50,uid=1000 $i /$i";done
How this works.
VBoxManage list vms - get list of vms in host
grep "\"default\"" | awk '{print $2}' - get uuid of "default"
xargs VBoxManage showvminfo --details --machinereadable - send this uuid to VBoxManage showvminfo to get params including information about shared folders
grep SharedFolderNameMachineMapping - get names of shares. They should correspond to the folder paths.
Otherwise one can use SharedFolderPathMachineMapping to get the paths and use them
awk -F '"' '{print $2}' - use awk to strip strings
for i in $(...) do ... ; done - iterate through results
docker-machine ssh default - connect to docker guest using docker-machine from docker toolbox
sudo mkdir -p /$i - since docker-machine connects us as docker user, go sudo and create mountpoints. $i is a parameter from iteration
sudo mount -t vboxsf -o gid=50,uid=1000 $i /$i - mount shares named $i at /$i as docker:staff
And it seems to work.
This can also be done from within guest with some minor changes, i.e. iterate over results of VBoxControl --nologo sharedfolder list | grep "-" | awk '{print $3}' and perform mkdir and mount directly within guest. 
. Sure, it's even more simple:
for i in $(sudo VBoxControl --nologo sharedfolder list | grep "-" | awk '{print $3}'); do sudo mkdir -p /$i; sudo mount -t vboxsf -o gid=50,uid=1000 $i /$i; done
You only need sudo in case you are connecting to guest using docker-machine ssh
I'll submit a pull-request first thing tomorrow and post a link here.
. Glad to help.
On the other hand I start thinking that we can achieve even more flexibility.
1. Allow selecting folders regardless of whether they are shared
2. As soon as user requests a container to be started, share and mount required folders.
3. As soon as container stops - remove the share (or just leave it be)
There might be some things to keep in mind. For example data-only containers. We should check for volumes-from and mount volumes from target container as well. We should also keep a registry of folders we have mounted to handle the situations when containers use folders that nested (i.e. container1 uses /Volumes/dev, container2 uses /Volumes/dev/bla) or multiple containers can use the same folder in which case we should only remove share when all of the containers that require it are stopped (or just leave the share as it is. It will be removed after boot2docker restarts)
If you like this approach I can create scripts that will add shares and mounts and remove them accordingly.

elmar-hinz:
I think this request is still as reasonable as in 2015. Also osxfs in the new docker-for-mac is slow and dangerous. It destroyed my database today.
People do all kind of hacks to get around this buggy design and to be able to use full-blown NFS. Dinghy is only one example.
https://github.com/stephank/docker-for-mac-nfs
So yes, it should be made easy to connect kitematic to a machine of the users choice.
. I gonna try. 
Description
For years I used a setup of virtual machines based on Vagrant, VirtualBox and NFS. For a long period I even stored them on USB stick and never suffered a data loss. I also used docker containers inside VirtualBox.
Now I was evaluating Docker-For-Mac with the official MariaDB container. To be able to throw containers away, I stored the DB on the local machine by mounting a directory, to stay on the safe side.
AFAIK Docker-For-Mac mounts by a FUSE variant. Within one day, upon the first crash of the Mac due to an empty battery, I was unable to reconnect the DB. The mounting itself kept woking.
It was an evaluation database, so nothing was lost. 
A single user report doesn't give a statistic. From my point of view it's very surprising that the NFS setup is working for years, while the Docker-For-Mac crashes the DB within 24 hours upon the first occasion.
I also experimented with FUSE ten years ago and it was quite limited compared to NFS.
Alternatives
I tried Dinghy to get NFS back, but it's still not mature enough.
Docker-machine within VirtualBox would be a solution, but lacks simplicity.
My current choice

Docker-for-Mac for the application for reasons of simplicity and connectivity with Kitematic.
DB on the local machine via Homebrew.

For a personal machine I can't recommend to run DB in docker containers so far. Technology must progress first.
Here I describe the use of my docker container setup in some details:
https://hub.docker.com/r/elmarhinz/typo3.docker-development/
.
dmitriz:
Just started using Kitematic -- seem like really great tool!
But sadly -- yes -- the font size is very uncomfortably small!!
I have impaired vision and immediately feel eye strain when trying to read it. 
Not only the logs, also Container list, Settings, Volumes etc.
Those are even more important than the logs, because I can copy-paste the latter to view in my editor but can't do the same with settings.
There is huge whitespace wasted, and then the useful content is crammed into tiny 1/10 of available space with tiny fonts. Why?
Letting user scale all fonts together as she likes, would really go far in terms of usability and accessibility! It is just a simple way of making the whole experience less painful and more enjoyable.
I see the objection right now is the presence of those '+/-' in the screen. But these would not add any noise because there is mostly whitespace around.
Please, please, don't ignore this -- it is a huge accessibility issue for people who are older or have impaired vision. They will be thankful for it!

ericmann:
Chiming in here because Kitematic's built-in browser view gave me a bit of a headache today. It's not that I'm running a container that prints a lot of JS, it's that my container is attempting to parse specific traffic sent to a TCP port it monitors. Normally, everything's fine. But if I alt-tab to the Kitematic window, my app will crash because of the flood of web traffic it gets from the browser attempting to hit the open port directly.
Being able to turn this off would be a huge win for me.

Subject: Re: [kitematic] Mac OS X fails to launch docker (#1485)
From your logs it looks like some of the certs may have failed. I would do the following:
Restart your VM:
docker-machine restart default
Regenerate your certs:
docker-machine regenerate-certs default

AnkyrinRepeat:
Sure, I refactored it to use the 383 code. The URL scheme is now kitematic://repository/run/[user]/[repo] to bring up the 383 confirmation page to begin running a container.
. Thanks for the additional comments, I moved the name generation to NewContainerPull. It looks like all the CSS from PR 383 is still in the master branch in styles/new-container.less.
. I put it in DockerUtil.run because when a user opens Kitematic using a URL scheme it will create the name before Kitematic has finished loading preexisting containers so if a user had a hello-world and hello-world-2 container it will overwrite the hello-world container rather than name it hello-world-3.  Would it make sense to only generate the name there or do you have another suggestion on how to deal with that?

Method 2

Open VirtualBox program
Go to File -> Preferences -> Network -> Host-only Networks
Docker Toolbox probably created a second Host-only network, probably named "VirtualBox Host-Only Ethernet Adapter # 2", double click that
Change the "IPv4 Address" from something like 192.168.99.1 to something like 192.168.99.2 (you will probably have to increase / decrease the IP every time). But it's important that the IP actually changes.
Hit OK. If the IP changed (it should have changed), you will be prompted for you "Windows Administrator OK" (or however it's named).

After that, the docker-machine and the Quickstart Terminal should work.

pitervergara:
I have this same issue (DockerToolbox 1.10.2 on Windows 7 SP1 64b).
After configuring my default boot2docker machine to use proxy, I was able to run 'docker pull hello-world' and 'docker run hello-world' via 'Docker Quickstart Terminal'.
Despite of that, Kitematic didn't showed images nor allowed me to login. The images screen only showed There was an error contacting Docker Hub and   the login screen showed unable to verify the first certificate, after submiting my credentials.
I tryed several other stuff, (exporting proxy upper and lowercase, set the CA path in my .npmrc, set strict-ssl to false via npm config, set  DOCKER_TLS_VERIFY to 0) but nothing worked. The only thing that made a difference was to set NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED=0 before launching kitematic.
This is my start.bat (placed on the same directory as kitematic.exe) :
set NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED=0
set proxy=http://proxy.my.domain:8080/
set HTTP_PROXY=%proxy%
set HTTPS_PROXY=%proxy%
for /f %%i in ('docker-machine.exe ip default') do set DOCKER_HOST=%%i
set NO_PROXY=%DOCKER_HOST%
set DOCKER_HOST=tcp://%DOCKER_HOST%:2376
Kitematic.exe

RobertJansson:
That should be perfectly fine in this case but you might want to limit the command to target nothing but the quarantine setting running xattr:
xattr -rc com.apple.quarantine /Applications/Kitematic\ (Beta).app
. The application triggers the security system in OS X that is there to protect your computer from trojans. It happens because the application is not wrapped with a certificate that can testify the institution of the author.
. You can not compare how an installer handle such even to what happens if you download an executable binary and try to execute it.
The quarantine flag is only set by quarantine-aware programs so I would not recommend anyone to use programs like that. It's better to get the trap and lift it with the command, because then you've got the heads-up and a chanse to think about it.
.

Maks3w:
For the issue about Certificate directory does not exists Kitematic should honor the value of environment variable DOCKER_CERT_PATH
. A workaround is create a link between ~/.docker/machine and MACHINE_STORAGE_PATH
For Windows this is
mklink /J %USERPROFILE%/.docker/machine %MACHINE_STORAGE_PATH%
For *Nix this is
ln -s ~/.docker/machine $MACHINE_STORAGE_PATH
You must remove .docker/machine  directory before run above commands
. @karneaud v0.12.0 it's supposed to support the env var
https://github.com/docker/kitematic/releases/tag/v0.12.0
.

urkle:
I've been looking into this, and the issue here is not the certificate being changed, but rather the application not being signed correctly.    Apple's documentation states that you should not be using --deep to codesign, only to verify.
What I use to codesign is my own custom made script that wraps up what XCode would normally do if it were to codesign an application.   This adds the proper codesigning requirements that running codesign bare does not attach.
What I did to get Kitematic to be signed correctly and validate on OS X 10.9/1.10 as well as 10.11 is I removed ALL of the _CodeSigning folders (as there were some extra files added in them that should not be there, probably from the --deep) and then ran my script on the app to code-sign it.
https://gist.github.com/urkle/93bddd0aaa7d5e692f0ec03df377f4d0
NOTE this script has been used for codesigning LOTS of released applications (Largely game ports that I do for Humble Bundle) and thus is battle tested.
.

(the below is a bit rambling so:
tldr; there doesn't seem to be a "what type of software is " service out
there [feels like there should be] and more general sources are patchy at
identifying software types)
I explored some options for 3rd party sources
I tried a couple of Google API's (freebase and knowledge graph) but it's
hard to get a useful result - same goes for WolframAlpha.
Knowledge Graph Search Attempt for Redis
https://developers.google.com/apis-explorer/#search/knowledge/kgsearch/v1/kgsearch.entities.search?query=Redis&fields=context%252CitemListElement%252Ctype&_h=3&
.
Searched around and it seems there's a gap in the web for categorising
software (plenty for Books and Movies, but hard to find the same for
software).  AlternativeTo had reasonable results, but not everything is
tagged (not sure if they have an API).  WikiData - had a look, but don't
know SPARQL, so hard to judge.
MediaWiki actually does pretty well in some cases, but likely to be quite
noisy results:
https://en.wikipedia.org/w/api.php?action=query&titles=redis&prop=categories
It seems like Google Knowledge Graph (and others), should know about
software (they certainly have the NLP to derive  
from description text), but I can't find any existing sources that do this
(unless WikiData SPARQL, or one of the Wolfram API's does).
It does kinda feel like it's something that should live outside of the
current Docker ecosystem, but that it should exist, independently, for use
cases like this...

awgeorge:
Just wanted to try and give some more information with this. Docker or the VM isn't an issue here, with both installed and running Apple remote desktop (ARDP) is responsive. However as soon as you launch the kitematic UI into the foreground, ARDP is literally unusable. For remote servers this isn't a great experience.
You can mitigate the problem by launching kitematic, starting / edit any configuration needed, then minimise or close the window, ARDP will be normal after it's off the screen. - But you have to be quick, the longer the UI is in the foreground, the more screwed you are.
Just because this bug is only highlighted when using ARDP or VNC clients, doesn't mean there isn't an issue when using the application locally, its probably just masking the issue.
I can record a video if that will help to debug the problem, but It looks like you are aware that your rendering is (probably) non-standard.

twocs:
I hate this problem. Basically, Kitematic has a button that says Exec but it shouldn't be used, because it will create a shell that is extremely annoying to interact with. The workaround suggested above is to stop using Kitematic (the Kitematic button called Exec), and that's the reason to close the issue?. > Hello, the solution was pretty simple to me: just type bash and be happy :)
Thanks so much. That's very nice to learn!. Could it be that even when we have switched Docker to use Windows containers, and Docker can no longer open Linux containers, the Exec button in Kitematic is still wired to launch sh?
Here is the error when I run a command like Kitematic might be attempting. 

PS C:\Program Files\Docker\Docker> docker run -it d9bccb9d4cac sh
C:\Program Files\Docker\Docker\Resources\bin\docker.exe: Error response from daemon: container 9962ecd27ce7313bd79783b69f51084e6d0abed92650d562cde8f1c01a5a2c35 encountered an error during CreateProcess: failure in a Windows system call: The system cannot find the file specified. (0x2) extra info: {"ApplicationName":"","CommandLine":"ps","User":"","WorkingDirectory":"C:\","Environment":{},"EmulateConsole":true,"CreateStdInPipe":true,"CreateStdOutPipe":true,"CreateStdErrPipe":false,"ConsoleSize":[50,120]}.

When I run this command, it works fine:

PS C:\Program Files\Docker\Docker> docker run -it d9bccb9d4cac

To work around this problem, it appears that we can set "SHELL" in Kitematic for the Windows container: Settings > Advanced > Environment Variables. Create Key: "SHELL" with the value "cmd.exe" or "powershell.exe", and the Exec button now works just fine.

Here's some commentary I have on this issue: I would suggest that because the system tray application for Docker has a menu item "Switch to Windows containers...", Kitematic must become aware that when Docker is in Windows containers mode. When this occurs, all containers will be Windows containers and are simply not going to accept 'sh'. 
My thought on how to fix these issues surrounding the Exec button: I'd suggest that the SHELL environment Variable is always visible. In other words, Environment Variables should by default list the key: "SHELL" that indicates the value "/bin/sh" (currently the default). This is apparently how Kitematic is dealing with the shell issue anyway, but because it's hidden, it's been a little difficult to really understand how to deal with the problem. This way, users get the default shell but can understand how to change to the shell they want. 
. As @FrenchBen has described in other issue reports, the bash shell is not opened when the Exec button is pressed. The sh shell is the default. Powershell does not interact properly with the sh shell so you should switch to bash. I am adding this text to the FAQ, which explains how to deal with this issue:

Kitematic uses sh for the Exec function. This can cause unwanted behavior, such as up arrows being displayed as '^[[A' in Powershell terminal. This is unavoidable, because not all docker containers have a bash shell (or csh, zsh, etc.). One way to use the bash shell, which does not have these limitations, is simply to type "bash" into the terminal each time that a new session is started.
If you want your bash shell to be the default shell for when you 'exec' into the container, then in Settings > Advanced, simply add an entry for SHELL with a value of /bin/bash. [1]

https://github.com/docker/kitematic/wiki/Common-Issues-and-Fixes. https://github.com/docker/kitematic/wiki/Current-and-Future-list-items
I note that "Add better error/notification support" is first on the Future list. I'm just proposing that the idea behind that be expanded to also include the commands that Kitematic is running as well as errors/notifications. I'm not sure if docker debug logging can be used to assist in the process..

bdharris08:
'grunt-electron-installer-debian' and 'grunt-electron-installer-redhat' will not work with windows, so you can just remove those lines from the devDependencies section of your package.json. 
Looks like those were added in the Ubuntu/Debian install merge - #1677 so that the gruntfile can use them.
Some googling reveals three ways to fix:
1. move the two packages to optional dependencies section in package.json (this already happens in the docker-modem and JSONStream packages - they optionally depend on 'chokidar/fsevents'
2. use a postinstall script and node 'os' to install the package based on the os type (however node would return 'linux' for both redhat and debian
3. expect new windows developers to simply delete the -debian and -redhat packages from package.json.
Any thoughts? 
I submitted a PR #1723 - with option 1, but need a quick install and build test on debian and redhat to verify the gruntfile will still work. 
. @FrenchBen @adomenech73 There may be a way to do this with npm postinstall script that conditionally installs those modules based on the OS, but I'm not sure that node built in os module can differentiate between debian and redhat.

rezonant:
Docker supports Hyper-V in addition to VirtualBox, and for those using Hyper-V for other reasons, using a different hypervisor is not an option.
This bug is due to a recent change in Docker, you can work around the issue by adding an entry to your hosts file (%windir%\drivers\etc\hosts) pointing docker.local to your loop back (127.0.0.1):
127.0.0.1 docker.local
This should work regardless of your hypervisor.
EDIT: fixed incorrect line

Blacktiger:
In chrome it tends to only maximize vertically - it actually depends on the width of the webpage you are on - if it's wider than the current window it will also expand horizontally (though not necessarily to the full width of the screen). OPT+Click restores the pre-fullscreen behavior of windows on Mac. I use it quite a bit as I don't like the fullscreen implementation when using multiple monitors so I often want to just expand the window quickly. Vertical only expansion would be fine for Kitematic I think as I mainly want to be able to see more log lines and it would be consistent with Chrome, although horizontal expansion would be nice.
. Interesting. Visual Studio Code is also based on electron, but it demonstrates the correct behavior. Opt-Click on the green button maximizes the window to fill my screen.
. Looks like the code VSC uses to maximize the window after starting it up is here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/a24a92384048d82dbb387483082ba1cfef4ee2c1/src/vs/code/electron-main/window.ts#L206
Like you said, maybe electron needs to be updated in Kitematic?

In Docker, I have a Postgres 9.3.13 image - with port 5432 mapped to local port 5432.
Initially, my problem was that I had a (homebrew) installed Postgres instance. So, when trying to start the Docker image, there would be a port conflict with the system installed Postgres instance.
I then killed the system, installed installed, and found the same result came from trying to start  second Postgres 9.3.13 instance in Docker.
This problem is VERY repeatable - either within Docker, or in fact for any port conflict.
The issue is SIMPLY that a Docker instance can't be started if the port is already in use. Unfortunately, the error reported is completely unrelated.
If a noob like me can replicate this issue so readily, then you're obviously approaching this from an assumption that I am dumb and I have it wrong.

then when I navigate back to 'Home' it shows

As invited on that dialog, I filed a ticket.
. It only seems to detect a port conflict if there is another container running on that port. Otherwise I can add a new container and assign it to port 5432

In Terminal execute:
docker run -ti -v /Users/myuser/folder:/var/www/html -d -p 80:80 -p 443:443 php:5.6-apache
The Kinematic will detect a new image with the configuration. :)
